title: 100th-staging-agricultural-show-postponed
story: FARMERS will have to wait until next year for the th staging of a Borders agricultural show.Organisers of Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society Show have taken the decision to cancel the  edition.The societys secretary Alison Renwick said the committee "felt duty-bound" to call off the showpiece.She added: ldquoThis yearrsquos show would have been particularly memorable, as committee members had already started working on a number of special projects to commemorate the th staging.ldquoThese plans will, of course, now be carried over to the  event and Irsquom very confident next yearrsquos show will prove every bit as successful as this yearrsquos would have been.Although the first show staged by the Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society took place in September, , the societyrsquos origins stretch back  years prior to that with the formation of the Selkirk Farmer Club .The new societyrsquos formation came after a public meeting was held in the Gordon Arms in May, , to "consider the desirability of forming a society for the purpose of organising an annual show of sheep and cattle".Descendants of farmers present at that inaugural meeting continue to live and work in the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys, thereby helping to keep alive the traditions and high standards which have become the hallmark of the societyrsquos past  shows.The organisers added: "We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone involved with Yarrow Show, including all volunteers, sponsors, traders, exhibitors and public, whose support is essential to the future of the show."The society looks forward to welcoming you back next year."

title: borders-college-students-deliver-medicine-vulnerable-folk
story: BORDERS College students are delivering medicine to vulnerable peoplersquos homes during lockdown.A total of  students and staff have given up their time to drop off more than  prescriptions across the region.The colleges work placement co-ordinator Verity Hislop said: "The students are quite happy to do it ndash they enjoy it."The college is working with NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council to run the scheme, which is being led by Ms Hislop.She said: ldquoAlthough wersquove no direct contact with the iniduals wersquore delivering to, we get a wave or a smile or a thank you from a distance."And we certainly know they are appreciative, from the expression on their face."If we didnrsquot deliver, they wouldnrsquot be able to get their medicines.ldquoThese are iniduals who fall into the vulnerable group ndash theyrsquove been told by the NHS they need to isolate.ldquoThere was a huge demand on pharmacies and a lot of iniduals in ious communities fall into the vulnerable category."We sent out a call to staff and students ndash but only those who are PVGscheme members."All the Borders staff fall under that, and also the health and social care students."Originally, pharmacies notied the NHS Borders Transport Hub about prescriptions that needed to be picked up.But now pharmacies are contacting the Borders College delivery team directly with their requests.ldquoThe Transport Hub emailed me with requests for prescription pick-ups from the pharmacy, said Ms Hislop, ldquoand then I would arrange for volunteers to go to the pharmacies, pick up the prescription and deliver them to the people who needed them.ldquoBut now wersquore getting phone calls directly from the pharmacies, with the increase in demand.She added: ldquoBorders College sees its role as supporting our community and during these unprecedented times there is a desire to contribute and add value by volunteering.ldquoThe college is exceptionally proud and grateful to everyone who is involved. This collaborative mission helps to protect vulnerable groups within the community and potentially saves lives.ldquoA huge thank you to all the volunteers, NHS Borders and NHS Transport Hub.

title: starbucks-reopen-around-150-uk-sites-thursday
story: Starbucks is to reopen around  stores across the UK from Thursday.The global coffee chain said it will open around % of its UK stores in the first phase of its reopening plans, which are predominantly focused on Drive Thru stores.It said it will also reopen a ldquohandful of takeaway-only stores as it continues with preparations to allow all of its UK stores to be reopened.Starbucks closed all of its UK sites in March after the Government-mandated lockdown was introduced.The company said it has been ldquolearning, testing and refining our operational standards every day behind closed doors.vw,vw,px, px"Starbucks said it has been testing its operations behind closed doors It said the reopening plan ndash which will start with stores broadly spread across the UK ndash will focus on ensuring the health and wellbeing of its employees and customers.The reopening comes after fast food retailers, such as Burger King and KFC, have reopened Drive Thru sites.Meanwhile, some cafe chain rivals such as Pret a Manger have reopened UK sites for takeaway customers.Starbucks has already reopened some of its sites in other regions, including the US and China.It said it has ldquotaken learnings from changes to its operations in China ndash where % of sites are now open ndash and the US in consideration of its UK sites.New safety measures at UK sites will include regular hand-washing for at least  seconds, two metre social distancing, screens at payment areas and the use of contactless payment only.The reopening menu will include Starbucksrsquo core range of drinks and a limited food range, it said.Employees have been paid during the closure and the chain said it ldquowill not be accepting any opt-in government support during the coronavirus crisis..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Starbucks to reopen around  UK sites from Thursday

title: exmoor-zoo-celebrates-birth-four-capybaras
story: Keepers at Exmoor Zoo in Devon are celebrating the birth of four baby capybaras.The babies, dubbed ldquominibara by staff, are currently about the size of a guinea pig but will grow quickly.Adult capybaras reach the size of sheep, measuring  inches high and ft long, and weighing about kg.Their Latin name Hydrochoerus hydrocaheris means water hog, with their native habitat the swamps and rivers of the Amazon and south America.vw,vw,px, px"Four baby capybaras were born at Exmoor Zoo A spokesman for Exmoor Zoo said: ldquoThe wet winters here on Exmoor and fresh Atlantic rain dropped onto the moorland is perfect for these animals as it springs out from the ground creating mud wallows and bubbling brooks.ldquoNot so keen on the harsh sun though, as they have skin which needs to protection from the sun with good mud layers.ldquoWe consider with a little shelter from the worst of the winter elements and direct sun they would adapt well here.The zoo is currently closed due to lockdown restrictions.It has been running a fundraising campaign, which can be found at https:www.gofundme f save-our-zoo..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Exmoor Zoo celebrates birth of four capybaras

title: public-use-common-sense-meeting-outdoors---raab
story: People should use ldquocommon sensethey meet people from other households in the outdoors, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab has said, as the Government comes under continued pressure over ldquoa lack of clarity in its messaging to the public.Boris Johnson unveiled a ldquoconditional plan on Sunday evening for easing restrictions in England, saying people could take unlimited exercise outdoors, travel to other places by car and should start going back to workthey cannot work from home.Primary schools could begin to reopen on June  starting with reception and years  and , he said, while parts of the hospitality sector such as pavement cafes and cafes in parks could open in July.But Scotland and Wales have rejected Number rsquos new ldquostay alert slogan, while unions and the Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer criticised the plan for creating confusion.On Monday, Mr Raab appeared to add to the uncertainty by saying people should only go to work from Wednesday. He also said it was fine to meet two people from another household as long as the households kept two metres apart.Government officials said on Sunday evening people should go back to work from Monday. They also said the new rules meant you could meet only one other person from another household outdoors.Speaking to the BBC on Monday, Mr Raab said people could now, for example, meet dferent family members separately on the same day while maintaining social distancing.He said: ldquoIf yoursquore out in the park and yoursquore two metres apart, wersquore saying now,use some common sense and you apart, yes.When asked latersomeone could meet up with both their parents in a park, Mr Raab said: ldquoWell, you couldtherersquos two metres apart.vw,vw,px, px"However, Mr Raab said people should not , he said.ldquoWhat you couldnrsquot then do, and this is why we say yoursquove got to stay alert, you couldnrsquot then go into the clubhouse and mill around where you will be within two metres of Words matter.ldquoClarity is essential. This is shambolic.On the issue of schools, Mr Raab said schools would be given ldquoclear guidance about social distancing and hygiene, adding there was a ldquomuch lower risk for young children getting this virus.But Patrick Roach, general secretary of teaching union NASUWT, said the profession has ldquovery serious concerns about children ing to school on June , adding no clear plan had been put in place.The Prime Minister is due to face MPs on Monday afternoon and will publish a -page document setting out further details of his ldquoroad map.If we all #StayAlertand follow the rules, we can control the virus by keeping the rate of infectionand the number of new cases down.Stay Alert ####Control The Virus ###Save Lives # pic JvGLxrDlAMmdash UK Prime MinisterMay , He will give a statement to the Commons, with more information expected on a Covid- alert system, use of face coverings, and quarantine restrictions for travellers entering the UK.The chairman of the British Medical Association , Dr Chaand Nagpaul, said the Government had created confusion in its messaging, adding that there was still ldquoa considerable amount of community circulation of the virus going on.He added: ldquoIf we now allow the public to go to local parks in an unlimited sense, and to go outdoorshellip what wersquove not heard is how the Government will enforce social distancing and how it will avoid a whole neighbourhood playing in a park, with footballs moving from one group to another, and spreading the disease.ldquoSo, Irsquom really concerned that there is no clarity.It comes as a YouGov Good Morning Britain poll of more than , people found the public is split on whether they support the changes, with % saying they support the changes and % opposed..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Public should use common sense when meeting up outdoors  u Raab

title: sisters-transform-bar-musselburghs-friendliest-pub
story: Rebecca and Victoria Fowler took over The Sportsman Bar in May last year, with a view to transforming the High Street premises.The venue has signed up to Best Bar None Scotland and Rebecca, of Tranent, felt it had made a massive dference in turning the business around.She said: ldquoHaving previously worked in The Sportsman, we knew what we were taking on but also knew it was something we could make work.ldquoThe pub had a bit of a reputation. We wanted to turn it into a safe place for people to come and enjoy a night out with a bit of banter thrown in: lsquoMusselburghrsquos friendliest pub.rsquo But we knew this wouldnrsquot happen overnight.Best Bar None Scotland aims to ensure everyone can enjoy a safe night out.The national scheme, which works through a partnership between local authorities, the Scottish Government, Police Scotland, Scottish Fire and Rescue Service and other organisations, works to reduce crime, reward excellence, and raise standards of alcohol licensed premises.Rebecca added: ldquoLicensing recommended we joined lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo and we were interested straight away since we knew we needed help to make the pub work.ldquoAfter speaking to the local co-ordinator and reading through the guidelines, we decided to use the lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo checklist as a guide to show us the safety changes we had to makethe pub was going to be a success.Rebecca and Victoria, of Wallyford, had both previously worked in the pub, which is at the junction of High Street and Newbigging.Rebecca told the Courier that promoting initiatives such as Ask Angela, designed to keep people safe from sexual assault by using a codeword to identy when they are in danger or an uncomfortable situation, had helped them achieve a silver Best Bar None award.She added: ldquoWe have now eliminated all the trouble and actively promote initiatives like lsquoAsk Angelarsquo.ldquoWe even hand out lollipops at the end of busy nights to help reduce noise.ldquoWe know that when our patrons leave the pub they are still our responsibility and need to get home safely.ldquoAll our customers now know that we operate a zerotolerance policy on trouble, including drugs.ldquoSafety has to be the top priority for any pub and, by working side by side with lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo, we know we are doing all that we can to create a friendly atmosphere for everyone who comes through the door, giving them an enjoyable and a safe night out.

title: extension-planned-school-prestonpans

title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. They have now been working from home for more than a month and have continued to support vulnerable and disadvantaged young people with ious issues which has brought about some ldquounexpected outcomes.Lynne Anderson, transitions development worker, has noticed that she is able to use her time more wisely by phoning her clients instead of driving up to an hour each way to visit them at their homes.She said: ldquoWe can use this situation to learn how things work dferently. There are opportunities to continue doing some of the activities we are doing remotely when weto normal.She is one of several staff members who have had to change the way they give support over the past weeks but it still focuses on many of the same issues. They provide help with filling out job and college applications, and provide young people with emotional support and tutoring. The response has also generally been very positive, with staff members reporting engagement levels of up to  per cent from their clients.Natasha McInninie, transitions service co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am surprised by how resilient young people are. I thought we would lose a lot of young people through this situation. However, it has actually made them engage more.Emma Scarclfe, acting chief executive, is also very pleased by how both Bridges Project staff and the young people they work with have responded to the current crisis.She said: ldquoBridges Project has adapted quickly to the unexpected situation around Covid-. Engagement continues to be extremely high and the commitment and dedication from staff to change their working practices so quickly to suit each inidual young person has been a complete triumph. Wersquore all very proud of the way young people have adapted and how resilient they are.However, there are also issues which have become ldquomagnied during the lockdown, for example, people who have dficult relationships with their family members struggle with being ldquolocked up together over such a long period. Others are affected by less income and need help with accessing food parcels, Universal Credit and other types of financial support.Many young people also need help to deal with the impact the Covid- crisis is having on their mental health. This is particularly the case for those who were already struggling with social anxiety or social isolation prior to the lockdown.Lynne said: ldquoIn the beginning, the young people thought it was fantastic. Now the reality of the lockdown is settling in and it is starting to become challenging.This trend has also been observed by personal development worker, Chris Nicol, who said: ldquoThe young people were dealing with it well during the first few weeks but have seen a downturn in their mood over the last two weeks. This is due to a combination of boredom and too much time to think but also not seeing their friends. They have realised how important those social anchors really are.He highlighted the importance of keeping young peoplersquos motivation and confidence up during these challenging times.He explained: ldquoI remind them that they need to focus on the fact that this will last for a relatively short period of their lives and things will go back to normal.Thank you for reading this story. title: goblin-ha-inspires-author-release-first-fantasy-novel
story: Goblin Hall, described as ldquoa humour-laced fantasy adventure for all the family, marks the latest chapter in the ied career of Peter Kerr.Widely known for his Snowball Oranges and Bob Burns Investigates series, he has turned his hand to another genre, with a nod towards The Goblin Harsquo, a reputedly haunted chamber that lies beneath the ruins of Yester Castle, near Gford.He said: ldquoI actually wrote the story, I think, about  years ago.ldquoIt was when my first book, Snowball Oranges, was just coming out, after waiting about  years to get published.ldquoI had an agent in London at the time and she said the way I write is very visual and I should have a go at writing a film script.ldquoI had never even read one but took her at her word and looked at the layout and general routine for laying down film scripts.ldquoAs for the The Goblin Harsquo, I had been to the old castle, with one of my pals who lived in Gford, when we were both about  way back in the s.ldquoThe place itself was not much to see, except peeking into the underground chamber, which inspired me.ldquoIt was bloody frightening and a very spooky place ndash it stuck in my mind.It was only two years ago, when transferring stories to a new computer, that Peter revisited his original film script and set about creating the novel.The legend of the Goblin Harsquo states that Sir Hugo de Gfard, known as the Wizard of Yester, made a pact with the devil to raise a magical army, who he used to carry out his will.Peterrsquos new tale, which is available from Amazon, features an evil sorcerer called Zorn, who has lured two young children into his subterranean lair as bait to ensnare his arch rival, a wizard called Mungo.It is up to the lovable but dippy old wizard to help free the youngsters from Zornrsquos clutches.The author, of Haddingtonrsquos Chalybeate, said feedback about the story was ldquoquite encouraging.That came despite the -year-old making an interesting revelation to the Courier. He said: ldquoI honestly donrsquot think I have ever read a fantasy novel!ldquoThat same literary agent, when she was trying to get a publisher for Snowball Oranges, told me detective novels were always popular.ldquoIrsquove never read one of those either and she said, lsquowell,you write one it will be original, evenit is rubbishrsquo.ldquoThat was the same attitude I took towards writing the fantasy novel.ldquoThe reaction so far has been quite encouraging.Peter was in popular s jazz band the Clyde Valley Stompers, who charted with Peter and The Wolf and were supported by The Beatles before the Fab Four made it big.Later, Peter produced more than  albums ndash including the Royal Scots Dragoon Guardsrsquo international chart-topper Amazing Grace ndash the biggest-selling instrumental of all time with  million sales.Thank you for reading this story. title: leuchie-houses-work-lauded-scottish-parliament

title: lockdown-birthday-proves-one-remember-neighbours-wave
story: Ian Millar has been recovering from heart bypass surgery at his home in Haddington and, under lockdown guidelines, has been staying in.However, daughter Susan was determined to make sure his landmark birthday did not go unmarked, and decorated his car with balloons and a poster asking passers-by to wave to her dad.And, last Friday, lots of families out for their daily walk stopped to do just that.Susan said: ldquoDad has not been able to get out of the house and is recovering from his operation so I wanted to surprise him. Lots of people waved to him through his window during the day and he really enjoyed it.Ian, who is originally from Linlithgow, moved to East Lothian with his we Jean more than  years ago, living in Auldhame and Seaclf before settling in North Berwick.A mechanic, Ian worked at Fowlerrsquos Garage and the Bass Rock Garage in the town, before starting East Lothian School of Motoring in .The couple had two children and, following the loss of Jean in  and retirement a year later, Ian moved to Haddington to be closer to daughter Susan.For his th birthday, Susan decorated the car in his driveway on Dobsonrsquos Walk, since they were unable to hold a party.Susan said: ldquoWe put a sign on his car saying, lsquoPlease give me a wave as Irsquom  today,rsquo and dad then spent the day being waved to by passers-by. He even had a visit from the police after a family member in the police in Edinburgh asked local officers to come around! Later on, he spent the evening on a video call with his children, four grandchildren and two great grandchildren.Thank you for reading this story. title: thirty-seven-new-homes-given-green-light-dunbar
story: Thirty-seven new homes on the outskirts of Dunbar were given the go ahead, despite concerns lodged by the community council.The statutory consultee contacted East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department when Harrison Hunt Ltd and Hallhill Developments Ltdrsquos plans were submitted in November last year.The scheme, which was approved at the beginning of the month, is a mix of three and four-bedroom homes on the south-west corner of the Hallhill area.Community councillors outlined  concerns with the proposals, including the layout and footpath provision, as well as the effects on habitat and the increased demand on education provision in the town.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, said it could be ldquoincredibly depressing to feel the views of the community council were not being given full consideration.She said: ldquoAll the comments we continue to make about connectivity, safe routes to school, play spaces, maximising potential for ecological building... all of that and we just feel asit is ignored.ldquoIt will not stop us making the comments but it does sometimes feel aswe are whistling in the wind.The development, to the west of Yosemite Park and Fall Avenue, will consist of: four three-bedroom terraced homes  three-bedroom detached and semi-detached properties  four-bedroom detached homes and four four-bedroom semi-detached houses.The proposals were approved by the local authorityrsquos planning department, which said the homes would be ldquoappropriate to their location given their height, size and scale.The planning officer added: ldquoThe proposed residential development would provide an attractive residential environment. The residential units are shown to be laid out in such a way that adheres to the normally accepted privacy and amenity criteria on overlooking and overshadowing, whilst affording the future occupants of the residential units an appropriate level of privacy and residential amenity.Access to the new development would come from Fall Avenue and James Kirk Way.A design and access statement included within the planning application notes meetings had taken place with ious local authority departments in a bid to address ious design requirements.It concludes: ldquoOverall, it is considered that the final design creates a well-considered, proportionate design that responds to the site constraints and the nearby area to create a positive design solution.ldquoThe result is a development that will make a positive contribution socially, economically and aesthetically to the area and enhance the amenity of existing and future residents within this area.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council stressed they ldquowelcomed comments from community councils.She said: ldquoIn this case, we consulted the community council back in December, and they submitted a response detailing a number of concerns.ldquoThese included concerns over house type and layout, increased vehicle movement and parking space provision.ldquoWhilst we understand that consultees may be frustrated when planning authorities do not always agree with their comments, we must balance these comments against the other material considerations of each case.ldquoIn the case of the Hallhill application, our conclusion was that, subject to the imposition of conditions, the proposed development was acceptable.Thank you for reading this story. title: nisa-store-steps-donates-1-300-charities-vulnerable
story: Pinkie Farm Convenience Store, one of Nisarsquos independent outlets, has donated essentials to the vulnerable and families in the area who are struggling with financial hardship.Support from the store ndash led by managing director Dan Brown ndash has included a pound donation to East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes, pound to Resilient Musselburgh and a further pound to Pennypit Community Development Trust.East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes provide fresh produce boxes containing all the ingredients needed to prepare a full roast dinner to struggling families.The charityrsquos founder, Jane Russell, said the donation would provide  local families with their dinner boxes.She commented: ldquoI set up the project in December  to give out free fresh chicken dinner boxes to people financially struggling in East Lothian.ldquoThe idea was to create a box of fresh produce so they had everything to cook a Sunday roast chicken dinner, and so the families could all sit together and enjoy a healthy meal.ldquoWe have helped over  families so far. The reason I set it up was because I myself have been in that position and, with three kids, financially struggling is so hard, decidingyou can afford food or gas.ldquoI wanted to make our project easy for people to ask for help without any forms to fill in or feel embarrassed.ldquoThe feedback and the support from the local community to help us is just amazing. The donation we received from Nisa will provide  families with our fresh chicken dinner boxes, which is just amazing.The donations were made via Nisarsquos lsquoMaking a Dference Locallyrsquo charity which raises funds in-store from the sale of Co-op and Heritage own brand products and has seen the Pinkie Farm Convenience Store donate almost pound, to local causes.The donations are just one of many ways in which the store is reaching out to support the local community, having recently launched new pound lsquoessentials kitsrsquo aimed at helping the most vulnerable people in the community and those who are self-isolating.Food kits have also been given to staff at Musselburgh Primary Health Care Centre and fresh produce contributed to East Lothian Foodbank, amongst other initiatives to help those most in need.Thank you for reading this story. title: grey-squirrels-targeting-dirleton-bowling-clubs-clubhouse
story: Dirleton Bowling Club, which dates back almost  years, is aiming to refurbish its clubhouse because of the troublesome creatures.A new roof would be included in the works, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Improvements to the footpath would also be included but a design and access statement in the planning application highlights that it is squirrels which are the problem.It reads: ldquoThe catalyst for this improvement project is the extensive ongoing damage to the existing clubhouse roof caused by grey squirrels nesting in the roof during the past three winters.ldquoThey penetrate between the pantiles and nest underneath them, gnawing their way through to the clubroom itself.The bowling club has been part of the social fabric of the village for  years, with the clubhouse and steps to the bowling green built in .The design and access statement also spells out what the bowling club means to the village and the potential consequencesthe proposals are not given the go ahead.ldquoIt is the only village sports club providing exercise and social, intergenerational contact through sport, and the only village team representing the Dirleton community, reads the nine-page document.ldquoIf the practical issues set out below mean that the clubhouse becomes unusable, then the club will be unable to compete in the bowling leagues.ldquoThe expectation of visiting teams is now much higher than it used to be, and clubs such as North Berwick, Aberlady, Stenton and Gullane all have new improved facilities.ldquoThe clubhouse is dark and damp and the roof sarking boards are being damaged and holed by grey squirrels.ldquoThere is no lighting to the path, which is also muddy and slippery because water pours onto it from the adjacent derelict hall owned by the council.Now, the bowling club, which has about  members, is keen to see improvements carried out, with funding being sought to cover the cost of the scheme which has still to be calculated.A new metal roof could be put in place, with consideration being given to it blending in to the historic surroundings adjacent to Dirleton Castle.Two windows are proposed for the south side of the building to improve the lighting in the clubhouse, while three semi-mature trees could be removed. The trees, according to the design and access statement, cause a number of issues, including not letting light into the building, while their removal would also prevent damage to its foundations caused by the roots.Access to the clubhouse would also be improved through the resurfacing of a footpath, while a new lamppost would be erected to further improve the lighting.Thank you for reading this story. title: queens-maundy-money-sent-church-elders-post
story: Alan Miller and Margaret Jeffrey had been due to travel to St Georgersquos Chapel, Windsor, to attend the Royal Maundy Thursday Service.The annual ceremony sees Queen Elizabeth II present symbolic money to people who have supported their church and community but the event was sadly cancelled due to the global pandemic.Instead, Alan and Margaret, who were both delighted to be given the honour, received the purses in the post.Both of the recipients, who live in East Linton, were shocked to receive letters last year inviting them to the event.Alan told the Courier he was overwhelmed when the letter came in the post and said: ldquoThe first thing I thought was lsquois this a scam rsquoldquoThe outside of the envelope said it was from Buckingham Palace and when you opened the letter it said Her Majesty invites you to be the recipient of the Maundy money.ldquoIt just seemed so wild and asit was not true but then Margaret got the same letter and I realised that it was right.ldquoIt just blew my head away.ldquoIrsquove seen the Queen handing out the Maundy money down the years and I never in my wildest dreams imagined that I would get it.Seventy-five-year-old Alan, an elder at the Parish of Traprain for more than  years, was due to travel to the service, which was to take place on April , with his we, Eleanor.At the service, each recipient would be given two purses, one red ndash containing a pound coinand a p piece representing the GB Olympic Team ndash and one white .Due to the coronavirus and travelling and gathering restrictions, both Alan and Margaret received their purses in the post.Margaret, originally an elder at Whittingehame Parish Church before it became part of the Parish of Traprain in , had planned to make the trip south with her daughter, Susan.The former housekeeper at Abbeyfield House in East Linton was ldquodisappointed not to be able to attend the event at Windsor but stressed these were exceptional circumstances.She title: yummikeys-aiming-spread-joy-sunflower-seeds
story: Elspeth Fawcett set up Yummikeys three years ago, an eco-friendly toy company that makes stainless steel sensory toys for babies.Elspeth has started adding sunflower seeds to all of her orders for people to plant inside or in their gardens.The -year-old mum of three is also donating five per cent of all profits directly to For the Love of Scrubs, an initiative set up to provide scrubs to frontline NHS staff during the coronavirus pandemic, and Womenrsquos Aid.Elspeth said: ldquoI really want to do something to help spread happiness and joy over the coming weeks as I appreciate that this is such a dficult time for everyone.ldquoIrsquove chosen to add sunflower seeds to all orders as this is something that everyone can enjoy, even those who are not fortunate enough to have gardens. I love seeing all of the rainbows in peoples windows but we can only enjoy these for the short time that we are out exercising each day, so my intention is for these sunflowers to be enjoyed for the rest of the time we are at home or in our gardens.On donating her profits she added: ldquoIrsquom a small business working hard to overcome the challenges that coronavirus has placed on all of our lives, but I feel this is really the right thing to do as my donation will hopefully help those who need it most right now.Thank you for reading this story. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make.In order for us to continue to providetrusted local news, I am asking you to also please purchase a copy of our newspaperyou have notalready.Trusted news has never been so important -and neither has your support.The Courier is not immune to the severe pressures brought on businesses up and down the land by the Covid- lockdown.Soyou are able to buy a copy for yourself - and maybe even for a neighbour too who is not able to get to the shops - then we would be very grateful.Andyou do wish to support us, please check with your local newsagent to seethey can deliver the Courier to you.There is also an E-Edition that can be read on your PC, phone or tablet - just click the lsquoE-Editionrsquo tab under the Couriermasthead on the homepage of this website for more details.We want to be able to continue telling you all about our community heroes: our NHS staff, council staff, teachers, carers, shop owners and shop workers, posties and bus and train driversand the army of volunteers in every town and village helping the vulnerable.But we need your support to do so. If you can, please buy a paper. And keep safe and keep well.Thank you.Robbie Scott, Editor

title: uk-lockdown-eased-schools-travel-sport
story: This will be a ldquomenu of options with the dates and times driven by the current state of the outbreak in the UK, he added.Ministers have faced continued questioning over the UKrsquos plan for lting its coronavirus lockdown, as European countries begin to ease their own restrictions.Italy and Spain are among those planning small steps to relax measures, while the Scottish and Welsh governments have set out dferent visions of how the current restrictions could be lted when the outbreak is under control.The next three-week review of the lockdown restrictions is due on Thursday, May .But how could the lockdown be lted across ious sectors  Heres a round-up of what you need to know.SchoolsUnder lockdown, schools and colleges have largely been closed, except for the children of essential workers, and it is thought this could be among the first restrictions to be eased.But Education Secretary Gavin Williamson previously said the Government had ldquono plans to open schools over the summer period, while Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said it would be ldquoinconceivable without some further measures in place.Head teachers have previously been advised to start making preparations on how schools could safely reopen, with the Association of School and College Leaderssuggesting a staggeredof pupils.ConstructionSome of Britainrsquos largest housebuilders ndash including Persimmon, Taylor Wimpey and Redrow ndash have already announced plans to reopen building sites in late April or early May.Under Government guidance, construction has been permittedin accordance with social distancing rules, but many companies halted work in response to the crisis.The Home Builders Federation said the restart is expected to be gradual, being dependent on how far supporting suppliers and services, such as building inspectors, mortgage lenders and conveyancers, can alsoto work.Activity will also be limited until the Government changes advice which effectively prohibits all but exceptional house moves.OfficesProperty services provider CBRE has drawn from its experiences in Asia to issue guidance to workplaces on how offices might approach re-opening in the future.It advises against a ldquofull throttleto work, with social-distancing measures needing to be reduced gradually and in line with public health guidance.It suggests businesses should establish internal taskforces to consider issues around access to PPE supplies, touchless technologies, temperature screening and reconfiguring work environments.Social gatheringsLimited social gatherings could be permitted in an easing of lockdown, but should be accompanied by extensive testing and contact tracing, one expert has suggested.Dr Joshua Moon, research fellow in sustainability research methods in the Science Policy Research Unitat the University of Sussex Business School, said the Government could adopt a ldquoslow release valve approach to the issue.He explained a phased approach might see certain sections of the population, for example healthy middle-aged people, given more freedoms initially, but he warned this risked the most vulnerable suffering the hardships of lockdown the longest.Dr Moon said family ldquoclusters could gradually be permitted to socialise, but could not make long journeys to do so, while most businesses remained shut.ldquoThe idea is that within those groups you can quite easily test, trace and isolate, he said, adding that it was harder to monitor for people moving around in public.HospitalitySector representative body UKHospitality has focused its energies on getting business support extended to places like bars and restaurants.A spokesman suggested that evenvenues were allowed to open with reduced capacity, businesses would still struggle financially.The All Party Parliamentary Group for Hospitality and Tourism has launched an urgent inquiry into how the sectors could reopen.This includes looking at operational challenges, reactivating supply chains, Government support and encouraging demand. A report is expected by mid-May.Pub chain Wetherspoonrsquos has said it plans to reopen its bars and hotels in June and said that due to it having larger than average pubs social distancing measures could be applied.RetailMinisters are thought to be considering allowing some non-essential businesses to open, such as garden centres and car showrooms, provided social-distancing could be maintained.Lobby group the British Retail Consortium has produced guidelines on how stores could prepare for the easing of restrictions.The guidance draws on lessons learned from supermarkets in recent weeks to ensure the re-opening of non-essential firms can be done safely.Advice coverslimiting entry and exit points, using floor markings to outline social distancing and keeping changing rooms closed.The guidance also suggests installing cleaning stations with hand sanitiser and disinfectant wipes at the front of stores.SportIt is understood Culture Secretary Olive Dowden has been working on a plan for major sports to be played behind closed doors when some social-distancing rules are eased.Weekly meetings are to be held between the Government, Public Health England and medical officials from sports bodies, with the issue due to be on the table when ministers review current measures next month.Key questions that need to be tackled include testing requirements, burdens on emergency services and the possible impact on fan behaviour ndash such as impromptu gatherings outside grounds.Sporting bodies are understood to be keen to resume full training safely as soon as possible.TravelLast week, low-cost European carrier Wizz Air announced plans to resume some flights from Luton Airport on May .Cabin crew will be required to wear masks and gloves on all flights and will distribute sanitising wipes for passengers, while new distancing measures will also be introduced during boarding.Mr Raab has indicated that officials are looking at possible checks at air and sea ports, with passengers arriving in the UK required to quarantine for  days.Meanwhile, the Rail, Maritime and Transportunion warned there was ldquozero chance of ramping up transport services soon, amid speculation of an increase on May  or May  when a new rail timetable is due.Last week, industry sources said no dates have yet been agreed or announced.

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience effort in Cockenzie and Port Seton has been helping launch a Fair Share hub at the Port Seton Centre this past week.The charity Fair Share delivers surplus food from supermarkets to the centre every Friday.The hub will cover the whole of East Lothian and support the centrersquos existing work to provide hot meals and food packs to families in need and children who would usually receive free school meals.Bryan Hickman, chairman of the local community council, which is leading the resilience effort, said: ldquoWe are still delivering food to those who need it but the Fair Share hub has been set up.ldquoWe receive food like coffee, cereal, milk and biscuits but this could change every week.ldquoItrsquos really good news that we have set this up as it will help us give other types of food. It will also help us financially because it is free.Meanwhile, the resilience effort is continuing to help those in need when requests come in, and currently has about  volunteers.A volunteer has also started offering a dog walking service.Contact detailsThose who require assistance can call the resilience emergency number on  . Updates are also posted on the Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council Twitter twitter CandPSCC and Facebook pages www.facebook Cockenzie-and-Port-Seton-Community-Council-.East SaltounHumbie, East and West Saltoun and BoltonFOUR volunteer groups are operating to help residents of neighbouring rural villages during the coronavirus pandemic.A resilience group, involving members of the Humbie, East and West Saltoun and Bolton Community Council, was previously formed.Alastair Beck, community council treasurer, said: ldquoVolunteers in the four village groups are supporting residents in their communities.ldquoAnyone in need of support, whether for shopping, pharmacy runs, etc, or who would just like someone to talk to should make contact with their village coordinator.Contact detailsPeople in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email shenajamieson@aol.East Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahoo.In West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmail.Finally, in Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMacmerryMacmerry and GladsmuirA LEAFLET drop to all residents across Macmerry and Gladsmuir last week led to the numbers of calls dealt with by the resilience team double.The team also offer a hot food service, and requests for this have quadrupled in the past week from two to eight.Stevie Sutherland, one of the resilience co-ordinators, said: ldquoI definitely envisage this increasing as it develops.ldquoSome might use it for a couple of days, some might use it for a couple of months.ldquoMaybe we can give a bit more help, askingthere is anything  they need.ldquoNeighbours are also looking after one another and they seem to be managing themselves.ldquoI think most people receiving meals are over .ldquoAll that happens is they are getting one hot meal per day. They might not be getting anything  but itrsquos just making sure they are getting at least one every day.Children have also been receiving wool in craft packs and are encouraged to make colourful pom poms, and hang them from their gates or a nearby lamppost.Stevie said: ldquoThe pom poms will start gathering pace now. Wersquove also put some posts up about it on social media. ldquoHopefully we are going to be inundated with them.ldquoWe want both villages to be decorated with as much colour as possible, in support of frontline workers.Volunteers at the resilience group are continuing to help with prescription and shopping collections.Stevie added: ldquoItrsquos just about getting that help out there.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, at facebook groups   and twitter MacmerryTeamMusselburghMusselburghAN AVERAGE of  lunch packs have been prepared and distributed weekly, as well as a daily distribution of emergency food packs by the growing army of  volunteers who make up the Resilient Musselburgh team.And about  free soup and sandwich lunches have been distributed to Whitecraig residents each week, Monday to Friday, by Graham Blaikie, who runs Mercat Grill, helped by Mrs Bennett.The team is also now providing freshly cooked meals.Community Councillor Margaret Stewart explained: ldquoHickory Foods, based at Eskmills, have offered us their kitchen facilities and staff for free to prepare freshly cooked meals which are delivered into the community.ldquoThe staff at the base identy, from referral forms, those who they feel would be most in need and make contact to offer this food support.ldquoWe are trialling this on a two-week basis, where a three-course freshly prepared meal is delivered to those identied for seven days a week.ldquoThis week  meals will have been delivered. This support is specically targeted at vulnerable members of the community, where it is felt that they would benefit from a nutritious meal. All meals are packaged and labelled with instructions for heating.ldquoThis will be reviewed after the first two weeks. However, we have been seeking feedback and, so far, it has been exceptional, with many comments of appreciation and thanks.She added: ldquoWe are still looking to build on our pool of volunteers to ensure sustainability, so anyone who would be interested in supporting us can register via eastlothian.gov.uk info  musselburgh_area_partner ship  resilient_musselburgh.As well as the pound, awarded to the Musselburgh Area Partnership to support the whole community response, Resilient Musselburgh has received a number of funding donations from community groups and organisations.Volunteers have been delivering information leaflets to households in targeted areas and Councillor Andy Forrest arranged for Musselburgh Post Office to deliver leaflets to all other locations.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .PrestonpansPrestonpansDEMAND for assistance from the Prestonpans resilience team increased last week, reflecting both the pressure families are under going into week five of the lockdown, and a wider awareness of the support available to local people.Allan Sneddon, who is leading the Prestonpans resilience effort, said: ldquoOur volunteers have started providing a dog walking service for several people who are shielding, and this is being co-ordinated on our team leadersrsquo WhatsApp group. This seems to be working very well.ldquoThe three local Scotmid stores in Prestonpans are offering a free home delivery service and, with the help of our resilience volunteersrsquo leaflets advertising the service, have been delivering throughout the town. We are also helping to deliver shopping orders.The Pantry, operating from the Pennypit, also saw demand for meals increase in week four, with  meals delivered to households throughout the town.The Pantry is receiving lots of practical support in the form of food donations from local stores in the area, and financial donations have been given by the Prestonpans and Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Councils, PSG Area Partnership, Prestonpans British Legion, Prestonpans Labour Club and Longniddry Villa FC.Prestonpans Community Council have also set aside funds to help households who are struggling to make ends meet and the Corra Foundation, Scottish Governmentrsquos Food Fund, the Prestonpans British Legion and RBL Scotland Pipe Band have made signicant donations to this fund.Contact detailsIf anyone needs help, they should telephone   or email prestonpansresilience@gmailIF YOUR resilience group would like to purchase copies of the Courier to deliver to residents who are shielding and unable to leave their homes then please email Courier Editor Robbie Scott via rscott@eastlothiancourier for details. Copies can be delivered to a destination of your choice before being distributed by your volunteers.

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-elphinstone-gifford-haddington-longniddry-tranent
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Elphinstone. Picture: Google MapsElphinstoneDOG walking, collecting prescriptions, shopping and much more are on offer from generous volunteers in Elphinstone.A spokeswoman for the community highlighted a number of services were on offer to people during the coronavirus pandemic.She said: ldquoThis care has included help with dog walking, collecting prescriptions, shopping, daily delivery of meals and food, a friendly chat over the phone or at a distance from the garden gate.ldquoA number of community partners have rallied to ensure that everyone is cared for during this Covid- pandemic.ldquoThis has only been possible with the operational support of East Lothian Roots and Fruits, Elphinstone Community Association, Elphinstone Primary School, East Lothian Council, Councillor Colin McGinn, Pennypit Community Trust, East Lothian Foodbank, Home-Start East Lothian, Walk With Scott Foundation, Heavy Sound, Social Bite, Tesco, Fair Share, Hibernian Community Foundation and generous donations from McInroy  Wood [Haddington].ldquoThis important work has greatly strengthened relationships and working practices that will continue to grow and develop long after we overcome this devastating pandemic.ldquoCollectively, this network has shown incredible reach, capacity, experience and skills as they endeavour to meet the needs of everyone in need of support.Contact detailsAny residents of Elphinstone who would like to request support can contact the team through email ndash colinmcginn@hotmail ndash or  .Gford. Picture: Google MapsGfordHEARING aid batteries have become the latest item keeping volunteers in Gfordrsquos community resilience team busy with calls for help renewing them.The resilience team has access to replacement batteries through the East Lothian Council community hubs soanyone in need should get in touch.Meanwhile, the team have also spoken about the ldquoprivilege they feel getting to know the stories of so many of their local residents.The grouprsquos spokesperson said: ldquoWe have been getting to know so many of our residents through talking with them and hearing about their lives we have one man who cooked for royalty and so many others with extraordinary tales to share.ldquoIt is a real privilege to get to know them.Contact detailsAnyone needing help can contact: Jo Allen, GCC chair, on   or ChairGfordCC@gmail Adam White, GCC vice chair, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, GCC treasurer, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, minister, on   or aschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonAN INCREASING number of people are getting in touch with community resilience volunteers in Haddington.The townrsquos community council has been at the heart of setting up a squad of volunteers to help people during the coronavirus pandemic.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the community council, stressed they would do whatever they could to help those who needed assistance.He said: ldquoWe have managed in the past few weeks to get our contact details out there a lot better.ldquoPeople are phoning and contacting us, and our volunteers are basically now really getting themselves into a nice routine.ldquoThey have got quite a few people that they are looking after week on week.Services being offered through the resilience volunteers are also increasing.Collections of shopping and prescriptions have been available for a number of weeks.Now, a dog walking service and getting tradesmen out to solve issues in the home have also been introduced.Mr McEwan took the time to once again praise the efforts of the volunteers.He said: ldquoI must say, the town has really, really done well and I have to thank all my volunteers and the people I donrsquot know about who are helping as well.ldquoWe have had people who have had maintenance issues and we have managed to get some tradesmen out to them.ldquoTradesmen are offering to help, some doing it for revenue but a couple doing it for nothing people are helping for nothing.Mr McEwan also highlighted that there was a wide range of information on the grouprsquos website, with sections set up to alert people to community help and coronavirus.On top of that, there is a section for food deliveries, ranging from butchers and bakers to prepared meals and takeaways which are open in the town.The community council plans to keep the list as up to date as possible for people.Contact detailsAnyone looking to find out more can visit www.haddingtoncc.org.uk while anyone looking for assistance can e-mail resilienthcc@haddingtoncc.org.uk or call  .Longniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryONE resident in Longniddry has started offering a free dog walking service for those unable to take their four-legged friend on its daily stroll.Those interested should contact Danni Anderson on Facebook.Meanwhile, the villagersquos resilience effort is still helping those in need and answering queries from residents.It is being led by the local church and supported by Longniddry Community Council.Sheila Jamieson told the Courier that people in the village have been helping family and neighbours on their own accord, so enquiries to her are still fairly low.However, she has still received some enquiries, such as people asking how they can get hearing aid batteries, food parcels and online food deliveries.She currently has  volunteers ready to help her deliver the resilience effort should the need arise.Sheila said: ldquoAs long as people are getting the help they need ndash we are still here and doing what we can.ldquoIrsquom overwhelmed and so grateful for the volunteers and the nice community.ldquoAll of the people in the community are coming together. We are coping at the moment and getting calls from the council with other people who might also need help.As with other resilience groups, it is helping with delivering prescriptions ndash but the local pharmacy offers a delivery service to those over the age of .Contact detailsThose who need any help or assistance can call Sheila Jamieson on  .Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranentVOLUNTEERS covering Tranent and Elphinstone delivered leaflets to every house in the area, with help from Ross High Rugby Club, reminding people of the help they can receive from their local resilience group.The number of people signed up to volunteer in the area has now risen to , as the number of calls the group receives also continues to rise.The resilience effort in Tranent and Elphinstone is being led by the local community council and overseen by member Mike Falconer.People are continuing to help out with requests such as collecting shopping, picking up prescriptions, and walking dogs.The resilience group is also helping Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with food deliveries, as well as assisting with its school hub effort.Contact detailsUpdates are also posted on the resilience Facebook page, lsquoTranent Emergency Response ndash Coronavirusrsquo.Updates, information and advice are also shared on Radio Saltire as part of its community information feature.Anyone needing assistance can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmailIF YOUR resilience group would like to purchase copies of the Courier to deliver to residents who are shielding and unable to leave their homes then please email Courier Editor Robbie Scott via rscott@eastlothiancourier for details. Copies can be delivered to a destination of your choice before being distributed by your volunteers.

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-dirleton-dunbar-east-linton-east-lammermuir-gullane-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonTHE resilience effort in Dirleton continues to help local residents and has launched a community larder filled with essential items.The Dirleton Area Resilience Teamis led by lead co-ordinator David Tait.Volunteers have continued to deliver food and medicines to the most vulnerable in their community, as well as those shielding and selfisolating.Further planning has made shopping and prescription collection easier for residents and safer for volunteers.Dedicated shopping days, and deadlines for food and medicine orders to be submitted, are in place.This reduces the volunteersrsquo exposure to potential harm at shops and chemists.DART has also launched the Dirleton essentials community larder via Facebook.The larder is stocked with essential items such as pasta, tea, coffee, toiletries, newspapers, hearing aid batteries and fresh fruit and vegetables.The group also continues to receive donations of fresh eggs from Ferrygate Farm and other produce from Aldi and Tesco.Other special items such as soups and crumbles are also donated.To ensure that all safety protocols are met, strict social distancing rules are in place.The larder is open MondayFriday and can be accessed by calling the dedicated booking line on   between am and noon for a -minute appointment between pm and pm.For those who are isolating, there is a dedicated booking line for deliveries in operation Tuesday-Thursday am-noon.This can be contacted on  .David said: ldquoThe larder has been proving a vital asset to the community and is used on a regular basis. All items are free and it does not cost anything to use.ldquoThrough successful grant applications for funding, DART has the unique ability to further support the village with continued stocking of the larder and will have a hardship fund so we can better support our community.ldquoAs an organisation we are continually assessing and forward planning for every eventuality in this crisis, and will continue to deliver on its primary purpose.ldquoThe community has massive spirit and itrsquos a marvellous place to live special thanks go out to all of the team at DART, all volunteers and, of course, everyone in the village, Archerfield and surrounding areas. More exciting things are in the pipeline and we will be sharing the news soon.Contact detailsIf you are in need of assistance, contact DART.coordinators@outlook or call .DunbarDunbarCOMMUNITY resilience volunteers in Dunbar have received a pound, cash boost.The townrsquos community council received funding from the National Lottery Community Fund on Monday.The community council is at the heart of the resilience efforts in the town, and neighbouring West Barns, during the coronavirus outbreak.The group use their large network of volunteers to provide essential free food and other supplies to vulnerable people, including the elderly, during the Covid- pandemic.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbarrsquos community council, was delighted with the funding boost.She said: ldquoWe have allocated the pound, to our hardship fund and we have a small  who will review referrals.ldquoWhat we are expecting is, as time progresses, people find themselves in need of some financial support that would make a dference, whether that is for school shoes or whatever.ldquoWe are calling them lsquomicro-grantsrsquo at the moment.ldquoThe sum pound, sounds a lot but in fact it will disappear very, very quicklywe do not manage it well.Referrals can be made by a iety of groups throughout the area, including churches, Rotary groups and debt services.It is hoped the referrals can then be reviewed within  hours and grants given to those in need.Mrs Swan added: ldquoIt will be interesting to see what happens.ldquoOddly, it has been quite quiet but I donrsquot think anybody knows what the repercussions are going to be in  weeks or three monthsrsquo time.The volunteers continue to provide lsquogood neighbourrsquo services on request, such as shopping, prescription collection and pet care.Dunbar and West Barns is split into nine clusters: Shore and Harbour Group High Street, Parsonspool to Kings Court West End to Countess Road Belhaven and Kirk Park West Barns and the Beveridge Row development Queenrsquos Road and the new housing developments Hallhill, Kellie Road and to the railway line Brodie Road east and north to the railway line and Brodie Road west and north to the railway line.A Single Point of Contacthas been assigned to each of the clusters to help direct volunteers where needed.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnershipand a member of Dunbar Community Council, said: ldquoWe are also finding an increase in the requests for support for the lsquoshieldedrsquo category being passed on from East Lothian Council.Contact detailsFor more information, go to Dunbar and District Coronavirus Community Helperswww.facebook groups  or Dunbar Community Council onwww.facebook DunbarCommunityCouncilEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsEast LintonVOLUNTEERS continue to be on standby throughout the area covered by Dunpender Community Council.The group, which includes East Linton, Whitekirk and Whittingehame, has set up a team of willing volunteers in response to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Dunpender Community Resilience Team is standing by and Judith Priest, chairwoman of the community council, said the situation remained much the same as previously.The East Linton website includes information on shopping, government, NHS and East Lothian Council advice, as well as numbers of all the community councillors.Contail detailsInformation is provided on the Tyninghame Village Hall website ndash tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk ndash while there are also details on eastlinton.uk.Every household in the area has also received a flyer, which features two numbers ndash   and   ndash which people can callthey need help with shopping, collecting medicines or prescriptions, or just want to talk to someone.Stenton.kim traynor and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.East LammermuirA FUND supporting residents of rural villages in the east of the county has been set up.East Lammermuir Community Council, which covers villages including Spott, Stenton, Innerwick and Oldhamstocks, has launched the new Covid- Community Support Fund.Leaflets have been delivered to homes in the area highlighting the scheme, which aims to support residents who have been affected by Covid-.Chris Bruce, chairman of the community council, said finance had been secured through Fred.Olsen, the company behind the nearby Crystal Rig windfarm.Instant grants of up to pound per application will be considered to cover essential expenses.A spokesman said: ldquoOwing to the nature of the crisis, multiple applications from the same inidual or family will be considered as time progresses. Grants above pound may be considered.ldquoAll applications for assistance will be processed as soon as possible, within three to five days.ldquoEast Lammermuir Community Council will, in the future, welcome back any financial assistance-awarded applicants, where they are able to do so.Application forms are available from the grouprsquos website ndash www.eastlammermuircommunitycouncil.org.uk ndash or paper copies can be sought from community councillors.The website also includes details regarding the coronavirus.Mr Bruce said: ldquoI would also say things are ticking over.ldquoIn Oldhamstocks, where I stay, we have had  uses of volunteers.Contact detailsFor assistance, go towww.eastlammermuircommunitycouncil.org.ukGullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneVOLUNTEERS throughout Gullane have been thanked for their continued support.Gordon McLelland, leader of the villagersquos resilience team, offered his thanks to the volunteers as East Lothian enters a sixth week of lockdown.Kind-hearted volunteers continue to carry out shopping and prescription collection and delivery for a number of Gullane residents, and have followed up referrals from the community centre.Mr McLelland said: ldquoWe have been encouraging people, through our Facebook page, to have food deliveries made direct from the local shops, such as Co-op, Nisa and Aldi, who have been supporting the local community so well.ldquoFood donations from Aldi and the Co-op continue, with any excess being donated to East Lothian Foodbank.ldquoThere has been steady demand for the hearing aid batteries which are now available from the resilience team.ldquoLocal volunteers have established lsquoGullane Scrubbersrsquo, making scrubs and scrub bags for the NHS and care homes.ldquoThe first batch of  scrub wash bags was delivered to the East Lothian Community Hospital.ldquoThe production of over  scrubs trousers is now well underway, with the sample sizes being delivered to the Muirfield care home in Gullane.Meanwhile, on Tuesday, along with food collections, the group is holding an exchange of sanitised books, DVDs, toys and jigsaws in the village hall, with strict separation procedures in place.In addition, there will be on offer lsquoart and craftrsquo packs for children who are in need of materials for play and school work.This will become a weekly event.Contact detailsContact can be made with the resilience group by emailing GullaneRTeam@gmail or phoning  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickTHE North Berwick Resilience Group fund has donated pound, to pay for visors being made by East Lothian school teachers for frontline workers.The visors are being produced by CDT staff in three East Lothian high schools ndash Preston Lodge, North Berwick High School and Knox Academy.The teams provide this vital equipment free of charge and health workers in North Berwick, including North Berwick Group Practice, care home team and district nurses, have benefited from this access to critical PPE.North Berwick Community Council chairman Judy Lockhart said the high school team have made some , visors and that availability of PPE was absolutely essential to supporting the health service and protecting staff.Gavin Clark, headteacher at Preston Lodge, is co-ordinating the production of masks.Claire Prete, faculty leader for design and technology at North Berwick High School, spent most of her Easter holiday making and distributing visors in North Berwick.Judy said: ldquoThe group operates on a request basis, so any North Berwick team or organisation that feels they need visors are welcome to get in touch with Gavin.All visors are provided for free.Meanwhile, the North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Team is continuing to shop and collect prescriptions for North Berwick residents who are shielding or self-isolating.One of the teamrsquos street link volunteers, Lisa-Kim Heron, recently embarked on her own initiative making cupcakes to raise money for hand creams for ward teams in the East Lothian Community Hospital in Haddington.Lisa-Kim, who works at the hospital as a social worker, runs her own small business, Sweet Tooth Cakery, by night and at weekends.She sold enough cupcakes to pay for  hand creams.She said: ldquoMy plan is to offer a contactless cupcake drop once a month in and around North Berwick and continue to raise funds for our frontline workers during this time.To contribute to the fund to buy title: shop-visit-sting-tail-scorpion-discovered
story: Adrian Nowak, who lives in Musselburgh town centre, found a dead scorpion lying underneath the fruit while out for a recent shopping trip at the supermarket on Newhailes Road."I went to Lidl to get some essentials and I thought about getting melon and found it under one of the melons I picked up - it had been squashed," said Mr Nowak, a chef at a local care home, who bought the melon.A spokesperson for Lidl said: "At Lidl, we pride ourselves on having thorough procedures in place to ensure that our fresh fruit and vegetables are of the highest possible quality for our customers. We are, therefore, disappointed that these expected high standards have not been met on this occasion and would like to sincerely apologise to the customer."We can confirm that it has also been escalated to our Quality Assurance team to investigate further with the supplier."Mr Nowaks photos attracted a lot of interest on social media with one post staying: "I bet you social distanced yourself from that as quickly as possible!"Another read: "When was in Royal Navy we got our stores in foreign ports. Chef checks bananas before go in chilly room, us two stokers there to ensure fridges donrsquot keep tripping. Opens box and spider size of a hand on top unit was alive but, because of being in cool temperatures, it lay still well three guys trying to get up a vertical ladder wasnrsquot easy."One stated: "I was stung by one of them in Guatemala - not pleasant at all."Another said: "Well this story has a sting in the tail.""If you import food from foreign countries its to be expected there are always going to be a few extra guests along for the ride . . . just be alert and be on the lookout, its part of the deal," joked another.

title: costa-coffee-full-list-open-uk-stores---plus-new-rules-customers
story: In an open letter,Jill McDonald, the CEO of the chain, confirmed the reopening of a number of drive-thru stores, plus the introduction of a delivery-only service at a limited amount of other cafes with Uber Eats.What did the CEO say - and what new rules are in place OnFriday Jill McDonald said: "Last week we made the decision to re-open two Drive-Thru lanes and two stores for delivery only in line with the latest Government advice."The safety of our team members and customers is our number one priority and ahead of these stores re-opening, we put in place new social distancing guidelines, enhanced hygiene procedures and are providing teams with personal protective equipment."We have been really pleased with how well our stores teams have been able to adapt to our new ways working, allowing us to serve great coffee, as safely as possible."We have also received some great feedback from our customers and key workers taking advantage of enjoying a well-deserved coffee break whilst on essential journeys to or from work."We will be increasing the number of Drive-Thru lanes and stores open for delivery via Uber Eats from May .""Drive Thrursquosndash Whilst open to all customers, they are intended to offer critical and key workers the chance to enjoy a Costa on essential journeys."Delivery Storesndash No customers will be allowed into the stores but they can order their favourite coffee from the comfort of their own home via Uber Eats, who will deliver."As part of re-opening these additional stores, we are continuing to help support everyone whorsquos keeping the country moving, delivering thousands of our Ready-to-Drink Costa Coffee cans to key workers near those stores re-opening, including hospitals, police and fire stations and NHS call centres."Itrsquos just one of our small tokens of appreciation to the people out there who are giving so much."Whilst most of our stores remain closed we continue to pay our store team members  per title: tesco-doubles-number-home-delivery-slots
story: The move comes amid a surge in demand from customers online.Heres the latest information from Tesco, including how to get one.When lockdown was imposed in March, Tesco was only offering , delivery slots to customers.This figure has since increased to one million, with the supermarket aiming to add another , slots over the next two weeks.To meet this figure, Tesco has recruited an additional , new members of staff to pick and prepare the orders, along with , new drivers to deliver them.The extra effort now means that the supermarket has enough delivery slots available to cover the government-provided list of around , people who are clinically vulnerable and donrsquot have a support network to help them get essential supplies.However, Tesco acknowledged that this number is still ldquonot enough for everyone who feels vulnerable at the moment.Tesco is releasing slots for home delivery online when they become available, but demand is still very high, meaning they are filling up quickly.Shoppers who are able to do so are urged to shop in stores or make use of the click and collect service, so that slots can be prioritised for more vulnerable customers.Click and Collect deliveries can be ordered up to three weeks in advance, and slots will be held for two hours. When this time is nearly up, customers will be prompted so they can extend by a further two hoursneeded.Customers who wish to book a home delivery slot can do so by registering online.Priority slots will first be given to customers across the UK who the government has advised are the most vulnerable. These customers will have received an email from Tesco to let them know they have access to priority booking.Priority delivery slots have an eight-hour delivery window from am to pm, or pm to pm.If you are not a vulnerable customer, you can check for available delivery slots on the Tesco website throughout the day, or select the Click and Collect service when you checkout.Tesco has imposed a limit of  items per order online, with some essential items restricted to a certain amount per customer, such as toilet roll and handwashing products.

title: dunbar-high-street-left-one-bank-tsb-closure
story: The High Street bank shut yesterday , leaving the town centre with just one bank, the Bank of Scotland.An announcement was made last year that the opening hours of TSB branches in Haddington, North Berwick and Dunbar would be cut. In November, it was confirmed the Dunbar TSB would close permanently.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the Dunbar and East Linton ward, was frustrated to see the bank close. He said: ldquoMyself and the council chief executive [Monica Patterson] did have a Skype call with Gillian Petty, area director for Edinburgh and Lanarkshire, and Carol Anderson, director for branch banking, and we discussedthere was any opportunity that the bank would change their mind.ldquoThey made the case that the number of people using branches to do their business is very, very limited.Ward colleague Councillor Paul McLennan was sad to see it close.He said: ldquoI worked in the branch years and years ago. Personally, for me it is quite sad to see it go.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, was keen to see the building brought back into use as soon as possible.She said: ldquoIt is very upsetting because it effects the High Street and people lose that convenience of having a bank within walking distance.A spokesperson for TSB said: ldquoWe have not taken the decision to close our Dunbar branch lightly and recognise concerns about the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which resulted in an even lower level of footfall in the branch and an uplt in customers registering for online and mobile banking.ldquoWe are contacting customers to help them use other banking options, including telephone and digital, and are working with the Post Office, which is less than a mile away, to ensure our customers can continue to access banking services.Thank you for reading this story. title: pupils-ve-day-film-premieres-online-due-coronavirus
story: The film was made by the schoolrsquos film club, named Peely-wally Productions, in collaboration with Longniddry Parish Church, before lockdown began in March.The pupils planned, shot and edited the film as part of the th anniversary of VE Day.Initial plans were to have a premiere and afternoon tea at the church tomorrow.Howeever, coronavirus and the current restrictions meant that that could not take place.The premiere has instead moved online and will take place through the Zoom online video app at pm.The film will also be uploaded to the schoolrsquos YouTube channel.The film includes interviews with three East Lothian residents who grew up during the Second World War, all of whom are involved in Longniddry Parish Church in some way.Louise Marr, an English and film teacher at the secondary school in Prestonpans, said that she had bought a lot of bunting specially for the premiere event to decorate the hall but is thinking of displaying it in her window as part of her own celebrations on the day.She added: ldquoIn our own way, we will still be able to celebrate the end of the Second World War and think about the sacrices made by that generation. ldquoWe ran out of time for the final edit of the film but are very thankful for the work of a former pupil and PL film club member for four years, Alastair Clarke. ldquoAlastair is now studying filmmaking at the University of the Highlands and Islands.
