I do know my limits though so I stay away from the plumbing... luckily in Portaferry my dad has a lot of friends who are alsotradesmen so they all help each other out.Q Have you a favourite pre-training meal to help you through a tough session A We usually train in the morning so I tend to eat an OTE DuoBar, the vanilla flavour in my favourite, and a cup of tea. When it come to racing in the evening, something easy to digest is usually what I go for... rice is always a winner.Q Name one movie you want to watch.A , I was planning on watching it in the cinema before the lockdown.Q Whatrsquos the best way to stave off boredom A Oh as a full-time athlete I feel Irsquove been preparing for lockdown for years. My le is basically train, eat, sleep. For me therersquos a few things I enjoy. I love chatting with my family, Irsquom usually on WhatsApp most of the day chatting or messaging and keeping in touch. I also love arts and crafts, Irsquoll be making postcards to post to my boyfriend and siblings to make them laugh, and currently my little cousin is teaching me the guitar via WhatsApp. She is a tough taskmaster, I have a lesson every Thursday and Monday and homework in between so that keeps me busy Q Have you any tips for training at home A Set yourself some goals that you can realistically achieve from home. We are allowed out for our daily exercise so you can get some cardio in outside, find a route that works for you and follow the guidelines. When it comes to working out inside, have fun. Find new alternatives, there are so many exercises we can do with body weight, or with stuff we have about the house so be creative and have a bit of craic. If you need any ideas check out social media, so many people are sharing home workouts. Give yourself a plan or schedule and try to stick to it. Being home means we can fall into the habit of sitting about and it can be hard to feel motivated. At the beginning of each week set out your plan for the week, what day, what time, and what exercise. Write it down and stick it somewhere you can see. Creating a routineduring these strange times means we can take back a little control.Q Name one documentary you want to see.A Anything with David Attenborough, I absolutely love animals and nature, and could listen to his voice all day.Q Have you discovered any new music or podcasts A My music taste is so ied but my wee sis and cousin Tara introduced me to Beoga and I absolutely love it. A lad from my hometown, Ryan McMullan also features in some of their songs, always a nice surprise hearing a weePortaferry accent as Irsquom listening.Q Is there one piece of housework you can no longer avoid A My own room! I actually enjoy housework, everywhere but my own bedroom. Irsquoll clean all day but canrsquot be bothered with my own mess!Q Favourite room of the house to spend time in A We are lucky that the Team NB Manchester athlete house is lovely and has lots of space so my favourite room ies depending in the time of day. In the morning my bedroom gets lovely light, it makes me smile sitting there chilling. Then when I want a bit of company the front room or kitchen is where we chill as a team and have the craic... andthe sun shines, which it does on the odd occasion over here, we have a lovely garden.Both Jip and Adam are enjoying learning how to puck about with my hurl..prettyPhoto

title: Recycling facilities to reopen
story: THE districtrsquos household recycling centres could reopen next week.Located in Downpatrick, Castlewellan and Ballynahinch, the centres closed at the end of March in line with the government directive to help reduce the spread of coronavirus.The Recorder understands that the sites will reopen, provided Newry, Mourne and Down Council can satisfy itself that the move can be managed safely and there is no risk to the public or frontline staff.Mid and East Antrim Council has already opened its recycling centres and Stormont environment minister Edwin Poots recently published guidelines aimed at paving the way for waste centres across the province to reopen.The reopening is expected to be discussed at todayrsquos virtual meeting between senior council officials and the leaders of the main political parties.Members of the local authorityrsquos senior management team are currently evaluating theenvironment ministerrsquos guidelines and developing a staff plan to allow the reopening to proceed in a safe way.In addition, officers are liaising with their recycling contractors, a number of whom have furloughed staff. The contractors are responsible for removing waste from all  council amenity sites, with early suggestions that it could take at least one week to ready themselves for reopening.With strict guidelines in relation to social distancing remaining in place, council officers are looking at the potential risks of reopening the sites and the required measures to mitigate them, with suggestions that ratepayers may have to book a slot to visit.Police and other statutory bodies, including the Department for Infrastructure, along with neighbouring councils, are also being consulted about reopening the sites.Council officers have suggested the recycling sites will open in a ldquophased manner and that certain restrictions will apply. Discussions with trade union officials are also planned.This Friday, the Northern Ireland Executive will review the current coronavirus regulations which could pave the way for the reopening of recycling centres not just in the local council area, but across Northern Ireland.Local councillors Willie Clarke and Billy Walker say Newry, Mourne and Down Council is right to carefully assess the guidelines published by Mr Poots and proceed with caution.They say the key importance is the safety of staff and residents, with the councillors suggesting that a visit to a civic amenity site would need to be classed as an ldquoessential journey under the current coronavirus legislation.Cllr Clarke says it is vital that the council approaches the reopening issue with caution, given that ldquocoronavirus is still rampant and people are dying.He continued: ldquoAny decision needs to be based on medical advice and direction from the Assembly.ldquoRecycling centres have not been classed as an essential service and people on their way to such a facility could end up getting stopped by police and issued with an enforcement ticket and sent home.ldquoThe council must ensure that all the Trsquos are crossed and the Irsquos dotted before the centres reopen. I understand there is a need across the community for this to happen, but my appeal to people is be patient for just a little longer.Cllr Clarke added: ldquoA phased approach to reopening the centres has been discussed by the party leaders. There is no point opening the centresthe contractors who remove the waste are not able to do so. A decision also has to be taken on what waste will be accepted at the sites in the short term.ldquoThe last thing we want is everyone landing at the sites, people getting out of their cars talking to one another and maybe not social distancing. People are still dying s a result of the virus and we must keep that in mind.Cllr Walker said that while many people have been cleaning their homes, garages and outhouses during the lockdown, the council needed to ensure that its civic amenity sites can reopen in what he described as a ldquosafe and proper manner.He added: ldquoWe need to manage the reopening process carefully and ensure there are not long queues of people waiting to use the centres, particularly in Downpatrick, Ballynahinch and Castlewellan, with tailbacks of cars spilling on to busy main roads.ldquoThe council does not want to put ratepayers at any risk and, in my view, is rightly proceeding with caution. It is not a simple case of opening the entrance gates and letting everyone in.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokesman confirmed that the decision to close the recycling centres is continually being reviewed in-line with government essential travel restrictions.ldquoThe council is currently reviewing this guidance and the implications it will present when it reopens the centres within the district, the spokesman continued.ldquoIf a decision is made to reopen the centres, residents will be informed via updates on the council website, social media channels and through local media outlets..prettyPhoto

title: Ryan bakes tasty treats for heroic postmen
story: SOME superheroes really donrsquot wear capes ndash they deliver the post.To honour the work of the often unseen heroes of the local postal service Ryan Bogues has delivered a hamper of his famous baked treats to the Royal Mailrsquos Downpatrick sorting office.The  year-old, who has Downrsquos Syndrome and lives in Teconnaught, has has to suspend his popular Ryanrsquos Cookie Box initiative, which he started over four years ago, because of the coronavirus lockdown.Ryan was praised by Prime Minister Boris Johnston last year for fundraising for several charities through his Cookie Box scheme where people donate money for his baked goods.Hersquos helped by his mother, Hazel, who explained a line in a recent speech from Taoiseach Leo Varadkar inspired them to think of local postal workers.ldquoMr Varadkar used the line lsquonot all superheroes wear capesrsquo and that struck a chord with us, she said.ldquoWe have had to close the Cookie box, but Ryan wanted to still help. We have an excellent postwoman and thought that the postal workers were among the very many key workers who were all working really hard to ensure that their service goes on as normal so we felt that they deserved a Ryanrsquos Cookie Box hamper.She added that Ryan bakes enough goods to donate two hampers per week since the lockdown and they have gone to nursing homes, pharmacists and hospitals as well.The hamper, which contained a range of buns, traybakes and lemon drizzle cake was well received by the  men and women who work at the sorting office at the Ballydugan Road Industrial Estate.Manager Donal Carabine received the hamper last week and said it helped lt everyonersquos spirits.ldquoEveryone at the delivery office has been working hard to both work in new ways to ensure everyonersquos safety at work while continuing with our service, said Mr Carabine.ldquoWe are delighted to have been recognised as being amongst key workers by Ryan and his mother and the baked goods are appreciated by all. We thank them for their generosity and I can assure them that the treats didnrsquot last too long.Mr Carabine said that the staff were coping with delivering items, mainly packages, and were as busy as they would be at Christmas mdash the busiest time of the year.ldquoI think the staff are coping admirably with the demand, as well as abiding by the two-metre social distancing rule in work. We have had to reorganise the office and stagger the earlier start times of some staff but they have all risen to the challenge.The Downpatrick office delivers throughout the wider Downpatrick area as far as Seaforde, Ardglass, Crossgar and Saintfield.Mr Carabine said: ldquoThe workers are more than holding their own in terms of maintaining deliveries and keeping themselves safe, although in some areas, due to the need to protect workers, the service is a bit later than usual..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield’s Leah battling to raise cash for charity
story: A SAINTFIELD mum is throwing her weight behind a gruelling event to raise money for charity.Leah McCourt, a champion mixed martial arts fighter, is undergoing a test of strength and endurance challenge for Christian Aid, which is responding to the coronavirus crisis in some of the poorest countries in the world.Over five days, -year-old Leah will be attempt to complete , exercises carrying a weighted bag used by combat athletes to build strength.Starting on Monday, Leah will complete the daunting daily task of , squats and lunges while carrying on her shoulders the crescent-shaped lsquoBulgarian bagrsquo filled with  kilos of sand and wool. Each daily session is likely to take up to three hours to complete.Leah is a professional MMA fighter and earlier this year she headlined a prestigious event in DublinHer fundraiser is in response to Christian Aidrsquos appeal to people to raise money by taking part in sponsored stay-at-home challenges as part of Christian Aid Week which runs from May -.Examples include completing , star jumps in the living room, a half marathon in the back garden, or the equivalent of a mountain climb by walking up and down the stairs.Leah is urging others to follow her example. ldquoThe current crisis has left many people feeling helpless, she said.ldquoHowever, it is still possible to do something positive and help others during the lockdown.ldquoExercise is important for our physical and mental health, but it also lts your spirits knowing you are raising funds to support a good cause.As the pandemic passes its peak in the developed world, the aid agency hopes that Leahrsquos endorsement will raise funds vital to slowing the spread of the virus in developing countries where there are few,any, ventilators and ICU beds.Christian Aid Ireland Chief Executive Rosamond Bennett thanked Leah for her support.ldquoLeah is a true champion and I hope she inspires others to take up the challenge, she said.ldquoChristian Aid works in some of the poorest countries in the world, and coronavirus cases have been reported in every one of them. We know the impact the virus has had here but poor countries donrsquot have enough doctors and nurses and very few,any ventilators or ICU beds.ldquoPeople wonrsquot get the treatment they needthey do fall ill, so itrsquos vital we do all we can to help make sure people protect themselves from coronavirus and help prevent the spread of the disease.In order to carry out its work, the charity relies heavily on the donations it receives each during Christian Aid Week.The majority of these donations come from door-to-door and annual church service collections, neither of which is possible because of current restrictions.Christian Aid tackles the root causes of poverty around the world and is currently responding to the coronavirus crisis in nearly  countries by helping to raise awareness of the importance of regular hand washing and physical distancing to prevent the spread of the disease, as well as distributing soap and improving access to water.To support Leahrsquos sponsored stay-at-home challenge, visit her Justgiving page at https:www.justgiving fundraising christianaid-leah-mccourt.To sign up for Christian Aidrsquos Active Aid campaign, visit www.caid.ie activeaid..prettyPhoto

title: Sisters caring for abandoned lambs
story: A SMALL flock of orphaned lambs have found a new home thanks to three sisters from Clough.The pet lambs, which are less than a month old, were abandoned by their mothers, but are now in the loving care of the Ashe sisters mdash  year-old Charlotte, eight year-old Ruby and Eliza, who is six.The lambs, named Lucky, Spud, Tommy, Shaun, Buttercup and Maggie, are too young to be put out to pasture and are being bottle-fed four times a day.Their new home is a field off the Claragh Road, they have comfy straw beds to sleep on and their new playmates are three young girls who canrsquot believe their luck.The girls are currently off school because of the lockdown and looking after the lambs is a fantastic way to spend their time between when theyrsquore not doing homework and helping with chores at home.Their mum, Cara, said: ldquoThe girls are loving every minute of it. At the moment theyrsquore basically living their lives around the lambs.ldquoAs soon as they wake up they go up to the field and give the lambs their first bottles of the day. Then they go home, have their own breakfast and do some homework. Around am they go back to see the lambs. After that itrsquos lunch, more homework and dinnertime for the lambs.ldquoThe girls keep the lambs in a field beside their grandad Erniersquos house. They play in the field most of the day and are kept in a secure pen at night.Each lamb has its own personality and they start bleating when they hear the girlsrsquo voices. They canrsquot wait to get to them.The girls are also learning quickly about what is required to keep livestock. They have a log book in which they record their weight and how much they eat.Adds Cara: ldquoCharlotte would like to become a vet and this is a great experience for her. In fact, all the girls are learning a lot and they would like to thank farmers who gave the lambs for providing them with this experience..prettyPhoto

title: There’s great work being done by the Irish in New York
story: A FORMER Ardglass man now living in New York has revealed how the Irish community have been coming together to support each other during the Covid- pandemic.Tommy McConvey was hoping to travel back home to celebrate his th birthday among his family and neighbours in Curranrsquos Bar in Chapeltown later this month. He is disappointed at having to postpone his trip, but says itrsquos better to remain in New York.Tommy, who is a treasurer of a global finance company, usually commutes by subway into the heart of the Big Apple each day. However, since the city went into lockdown on March , Tommy has been self-isolating at home with his girlfriend, Lia.The former Crew Road resident has been living in New York since ,after he completed his Masters degree at Queenrsquos University Belfast, and says he only intended staying for six weeks.That same year he flew to Dublin on September  mdash the same day as the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, which he and friends had visited the previous day.ldquoWe had taken pictures with the security guards and other workers and it still haunts me wonderingthose guys were able to make it out alive, he says.Tommy says that  years on fear has ed to the streets of New York.ldquoAt the beginning of the pandemic back in early March our company was swt to respond. We put social distancing measures in place and rotated staff on a sht basis so that only a third of workers were in the office each day.ldquoWe knew the virus was going to get more severe so after we learned the St Patrickrsquos Day parade was to be cancelled we took that as a signal and mandated that all staff should stay at home.Tommy says the sweeping changes have left an eerie feeling in their wake.ldquoIn the first few weeks the only workers that remained in the city centre were builders availing of free movement and the empty streets to get ahead with development projects, but they too were forced to quit, he said.ldquoTraffic has all but ceased, apart from a few ambulances and delivery trucks.ldquoThe economic impact of coronavirus has been devastating, particularly for the Irish who have found themselves furloughed off, out of work and not entitled to any government aid.ldquoA charity has been set up called Slainte  which was formed with the sole intention of alleviating the suffering that many have been going through and to help those less fortunate to get through it.Tommy is also a leading figure in the GAA in New York which is supporting Slainte .At the weekend local Gaelic footballers in the city ran a combined distance of , kilometres, which is the equivalent of running theof Ireland, from Malin Head in Donegal to Mizzen Head in Cork mdash and back.The event was in place of a cancelled Gaelic football tournament and all proceeds went to Slainte .ldquoOver half of the people who have applied for help from Slainte  are in the hospitality industry which looks to be one of the last groups that willto work in all likelihood.ldquoThere is also a lot of great work being done by other Irish community groups in New York.Tommy says it is very encouraging to see the Irish community pull together during a time like this.He said: ldquoThe Irish are renowned for putting their shoulder to the wheel in times of adversity and the last few weeks have been no dferent.ldquoWersquore looking after each other as we always have done when hardship strikes.Tommy says people can still make donations to Slainte  by going to the link www.slainte.org..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. The Ulster Farmersrsquo Union also used the opportunity to discuss the implications for local farmers post Brexit.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: sandra chapman boris must play fair older generation
story: Labour ‘must take action’ over Bobby Sands tweet say unionistsPolice say they ‘sensitively monitored situation’ as images emerge of yet another large republican funeral gatheringNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionColumnistsSandra Chapman: Boris must play fair with the older generationThis coronavirus episode continues to dominate our lives and I’m beginning to suspect it is my older generation which may have to suffer the longest lockdown.By Sandra ChapmanSaturday, th May , : amUpdated Saturday, th May , : am""Editorial Image : Other rd PartyMonths have been mentioned, a penalty sure to cause major problems and for what purpose The Government doesn’t appear to know what to do with us, only promising to ‘clary the lockdown rules’ relating to older people soon. In anticipation of what none of us wants to hear, politicians at Westminister got an earful from no less a person than Baroness Altmann, a former pensions minister, who warned there could be ‘social unrest’the over s are ‘forced to endure a longer lockdown than the younger generation’.This is a country where once upon a time women could retire at  and men at  – as that was regarded as old age. But people have been living longer due to better living standards, the results of all the hard work the baby boomer generation put in right up to the present time. This appears to have emboldened successive Governments to raise the age of retirement age for both men and women. More money in the public coffers is the result. Sandra Chapman column : JPIMedia " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...The retirement age may well rise in the longer term to  yearsnot , a prospect feared by every worker in the country. Yet, politicians remain silent on this. Putting up the age of retirement also means there will be less years for state pensions to be paid out.I worry at what appears to be the increasing use of the term ‘healthy over s’. What exactly does that mean  Few people in this age category I suspect enjoy perfect health, otherwise GPs across the land wouldn’t be advising them to take statins to keep blood pressure levels down. Women have been encouraged to take HRT long after menopause, even staying on it for leneeds be. These le enhancers, as some medical people appear to regard them, may be just the ticket. But how are we to know since the latter, statins, are relatively new to the people whilst HRT still attracts controversy Do either of these treatments increase longevity  We simply don’t know the answer to that question.Locking down the over-s, many of whom will still be paying tax to the Government, could be interpreted in many ways. I will take the kindly approach and suggest that the Government will need all the scope it has to get the economy back up and running schools will have to be re-opened and plans will have to be laid for the possibility of a future pandemic since the current one caught everyone by surprise and left the country on its knees. With the absolute necessity to get people back to work and paying income tax, the Government must have thought the oldies could wait and since many of them will have ious ailments it could be dressed up as ‘protecting them’. One Cabinet minister has said the whole thing ‘is to be based around consent rather than compulsion’.That’s fine, but it appears no one asked us first whether we wanted to be lockdowned for longer or left to do our own thing.I certainly do not want to be on lockdown for any more weeks than I have to because once you hit your s le seems to go by in a flash. It seems no time since my children were clinging to my skirts wanting me to play in the garden. Anniversaries and birthdays came and went with me so busy I scarcely noticed. The children grew up with me hardly noticing the years go by and then they were off to university. They found themselves wives, leaving us at home, on our own, wondering where all the years had gone. But still we felt young, still able to work and go on holiday.We hardly noticed our th birthdays, then last year it was the th wedding anniversary. We still have brothers and sisters and the only recognition of ageing is when the much older members in the wider family, the true older generation, pass on. I don’t think I’m the older generation yet.""Get the latest news on the CoronavirusWe have launched a daily public interest bulletin to deliver all the updates and vital information to your inboxSign Up Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-eKZiaR jSxAXl"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-jtRlXQ cUfQBC"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-eKZiaR jSxAXl"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-jtRlXQ cUfQBC"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportIrish League FootballWhats OnLestyleFarming LeMore from the News LetterAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsNewsletterArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-dqBHgY sc-gxMtzJ bAegnq"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policy News you can trust since Sign in"Edit AccountSign OutSubscribeNews" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . story: , council staff in NI face being furloughed, warns unionHomes evacuated and roads closed in NI security alert - PSNI urge public to remain vigilantNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionPManything is being too cautious, and rest of UK all the more soThe prime minister last night in an address to the nation announced a modestto normality.By EditorialMonday, th May , : am""News Letter editorialBoris Johnson talked atabout the risks of Covid-, and the progress that had been made.He then tentatively outlined a relaxation of lockdown as it applies to England.The PM’s message shted from ‘Stay At Home’ to ‘Stay Alert’ and said that any changes would be dependent on ongoing progress against the virus.The fact that it hasbegun to flare up again in South Korea, one of the nations that had the best response to the crisis, is a reminder of the dangers of later surges of the pandemic. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Mr Johnson has been attacked for sending mixed messages, but in fact he was right to suggest a path forward.If anything, his proposals were too modest: primary schools in England might begin toin June, there will be no restrictions on exercise and people will be allowed to enjoy the sun in a park or to drive to a destination for a walk.Most signicantly of all, Mr Johnson said that while the message previously was that people should work from homepossible and go to workit was essential, now they should be actively encouraged to go to workthey cannot work from home, ideally not using public transport.While the virus might be at a slightly later stage in the cycle on the Celtic fringe of the UK, it is becoming clear that the less densely populated three nations —Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland — have been fortunate to be less badly hit.Also, there are political motives clearly at play. title: coronavirus circus teaching older people new tricks lockdown
story: Phased strategic approach to NI recovery to be discussed by executive todayTwo viable devices discovered during security alert - the consequences of this could have been devastatingNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsPeopleCoronavirus: The circus teaching older people new tricks in lockdownGRAEME COUSINS finds out how a Northern Ireland circus school has managed to adapt its workshops during lockdownBy Graeme CousinsMonday, th May , : am""Taking part in an Ageility workship with the Streetwise Circus : Other rd PartyWhile some people have taken advantage of lockdown to indulge in relaxing pastimes, others have gone for the juggler.You might think the teaching of circus skills would have been curtailed by current social distancing restrictions, but older people throughout Northern Ireland are picking up new tricks thanks to online advances.Jim Webster from the Streetwise Community Circus explained how he and other tutors have been able to deliver a workshop teaching skills such as juggling, unicycling and stilt walking during lockdown.He said: “Immediately after the lockdown we would have had been going to run workshops for older people throughout Northern Ireland. That was a new project we’d started up in Fermanagh, North Down and Ards, Mid and East Antrim and the Newry area. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...“We have for years done a lot of work with people with learning disabilities as well as youth groups.”He said the  freelance tutors at the circus all have a wide range of skills including street entertainers, percussionists, a film maker.In terms of adapting to lockdown Jim said: “When the lockdown restrictions came the first thing we did was put on videos which relate to what you can do at home, things like how to make juggling equipment.“We’re learning as we go. The next stage is we’ve decided to lend our kit. “Where we had workshop equipment that should have been being used at the moment we might as well lend it out to participants who are now stuck at home.“We’ve older people in Fermanagh, we’ve just got to work out how to get it to them.”He continued: “For the next stage we’ve tied in with a group in the north east who work with asylum seekers and refugees, they would be more advanced than us in terms of working with Zoom. We’re learning from them on how to use Zoom for classes.“One of our guys is doing a session on a Friday morning using Zoom for the older people who would normally have come in.“We are now working with them to seewe can actively teach across Zoom.“We all know about Zoom as a meeting medium, but can I stand in a room here and observe someone’s juggling close enough through Zoom that I can give them active guidance  It then opens up the potential to teach online one-to-one or to groups of people.“It takes away the need to physically be anywhere.“We’ve had a committee meeting on Zoom and it was the first time we’ve had % attendance. I think we had more done in  minutes and had more good ideas than ever before.“Because circus is a physical activity, you have to think a little bit more deeply about what goes on when you’re teaching.“You realise that you’ve got to encourage people, inspire people and engage with people.“If you can do that online we can reach people who are isolating. When you think of those people in Fermanagh, they were always very rural, and they can now link with us better than ever.”Streetwise Community Circus receives funding from Arts Council, Belfast City Council and Lottery Community Fund.Jim said the tutors were offering all the circus skills apart from aerial: “We can only offer aerial in the centre that we’re based in.“You’ve got juggling, unicycling, stilt walking, things like that, diablo, hat tricks, poi – which is the ribbon that you spin around yourself.“The simplest thing to learn I would say is scarf juggling because that gets the pattern going. You can do a lot of stuff with less than three balls. With one scarf you can pick up the co-ordination needed to juggle.“You start with one scarf and realise you can flip it around dferent ways and catch it, then it’s game on. “Once you’ve started, the circus is about getting the skill, practising it, then improving with practice.“You don’t put a ceiling on it, there’s no starting point of entry and there’s no ceiling.”Asked how useful it was for older people and people with learning dficulties to learn circus skills, Jim said: “There’s a couple of aspects. Circus is not for everybody, not all older people want to juggle, but people who do try circus skills, the feedback is they love it because it’s really invigorating. “On a Friday morning I’ve got video footage of older people kne throwing. They’re loving it.“We’ve had people in their s stilt walking in the Lisburn Carnival, they’re active and are loving the fact they can do these new things.”He added: “Disability is the same. We do a summer school for adults with learning disabilities. They devise their own shows. They’re not defined by their disability when they’re there. They’re defined by their talents.“I can think of a couple of iniduals who would be on the autistic spectrum, they have very limited verbal communication but can unicycle backwards. Those particular iniduals have delivered lines on stage as part of a show. You’re challenging stereotypes towards people from these groups.“It’s a hard sell initially. Circus is not for everybody butpeople engage with it they get a real lt and it influences other areas of their lives.“There’s another spin-off from the older people workshops – we’ve found techniques for working with people with dementia.“Circus is in the moment, it’s physical. When you juggle you’ve activated parts of the brain that are beneficial.“We’ve actually designed sit-down circus skills, we’ve all sorts of table top stuff. “We’ve found there’s a lot of groups of old people who meet up and talk about what they can’t do, the health stuff, trying to go on computers. So we’re just having some fun with something that is not important but it lts you because you say, ‘wow, I didn’t know I could do that’.”""Get the latest news on the CoronavirusWe have launched a daily public interest bulletin to deliver all the updates and vital information to your inboxSign Up Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-eKZiaR jSxAXl"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-jtRlXQ cUfQBC"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-eKZiaR jSxAXl"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-jtRlXQ cUfQBC"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportIrish League FootballWhats OnLestyleFarming LeMore from the News LetterAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsNewsletterArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-dqBHgY sc-gxMtzJ bAegnq"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policy News you can trust since Sign in"Edit AccountSign OutSubscribeNews" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls keir starmers labour leadership win ray hope difficult times
story: The MP for Holborn and St Pancras defeated Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir, who won on the first round of voting with . per cent of ballots cast.Stephen called Sir Keirs ascension a ray of hope, and said that the party should now turn its attention to winning elections.He said: ldquoI am so pleased that Keir Starmer has become UK Labour leader.ldquoThe ray of hope Keir represents could not come at a more critical time.ldquoHis message of unity has won over members up and down the country ndash and we need to ensure that we model that through the whole of the UK Labour Party.ldquoAnd it is clear that Labour comes out of this contest stronger, with Rebecca and Lisa running really positive campaigns.ldquoThe UK General Election result in December was devastating for Labour and we cannot repeat it."Thatrsquos why Keirrsquos campaign was all about focussing the party on winning elections. Only then can we change peoplersquos lives."Welsh Labour, and First Minister Mark Drakeford will now be working closely with Keir to ensure we win the Senedd elections next year.ldquoKeir has already shown his commitment to Wales and Welsh Labour, and personally visited Cardf South and Penarth with me just a few months ago to meet local residents.ldquoWe also need to restore peoplersquos trust in the Labour Party as a force for good - a crucial part of that is tackling antisemitism."I know that Keir has the values, vision and moral compass needed to fight for justice at home and abroad ndash and that is needed more than ever.ldquoNobody could have predicted the campaign ending in these hugely dficult circumstances - and regardless of the result, our primary thoughts at the moment are with all those affected by coronavirus, and our brilliant NHS and social care staff, and key workers up and down the country who are keeping us going and saving lives every day."The Labour Partyrsquos number one priority right now is working across party lines to help the country get through this.ldquoI am also delighted Angela Rayner has been elected our new UK Deputy Leader ndash someone who I have campaigned with on a range of issues over many years. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: virus decimated marie curie hospice charity income penarth
story: End of le patients who do not want to be in hospital need to be moved to a more appropriate setting, as beds in critical care units are urgently required for patients who need lesaving treatment.The charity, which relies upon public donations and fundraising events needs to raise pound million a year to continue to run its essential frontline services across Wales.However, chief executive Matthew Reed has said the charityrsquos income has been lsquodecimatedrsquo due to the outbreak.Rachel Moses-Lloyd from Marie Curie in Wales said: ldquoWhen the NHS and public need us most, we are facing huge dficulties raising our vital funds."Along with the cancellation of hundreds of high street and supermarket collections, wersquore now losing income from the closure of our charity shops and from cancelled fundraising events."The Marie Curie Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth cares for around , people each year.Its manager, Sarah Lloyd-Davies, said: ldquoAcross Marie Curie we have provided care to a few terminally ill patients who have tested positive for coronavirus or are suspected of having it and do expect this to continue in future. For reasons of patient confidentiality we are not able to discuss specic cases of care from the hospice or from the community nursing care we provide.ldquoOur hospice staff and nursing teams across Cardf and the Vale are very much on the frontline and have an important job in keeping patients out of hospital to relieve pressure on the NHS. That is important now more than ever given the coronavirus crisis. The health and wellbeing of our patients, their loved ones, and our staff is our top priority and across the hospice and community we are taking steps to protect them. This includes the use of PPE and, in-line with other providers of care, including the NHS, we have amended our visiting rules at the hospice.ldquoWith regards PPE, unfortunately, our hospice and community nursing service have been facing the same issues as the NHS in terms of getting all the equipment they need. We are screening patients with a phone call before attending their homes and staff will wear the appropriate PPE equipment during every household visit. However, we can only do this when we have the right PPE equipment available and are grateful to have recently received support from our colleagues at the Cardf and the Vale University Health Board to gain access to some PPE through their supply, for which we give our thanks.ldquoHowever we are always in need of more supplies to continue to provide vital end of le care to people living with a terminal illness, especially at this dficult time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: A total of  of these cases were in the Vale of Glamorgan where a further  people tested positive on Wednesday.In total  people have been tested for the virus in the Vale, of whom . per cent have tested positive.Meanwhile, the virus has claimed  more lives across Wales, meaning  have now passed away with the disease.There were  new cases of covid- reported in Wales, taking the total number of confirmed cases to ,, although the true number of cases is likely to be higher.Dr Robin Howe, Incident Director for the Novel Coronavirusoutbreak response at Public Health Wales, said: ldquoWe offer our condolences to families and friends affected, and we ask those reporting on the situation to respect patient confidentiality.ldquoPublic Health Wales has conducted more than , tests for Novel Coronaviruson more than , iniduals since the start of this outbreak.It comes as a Welsh Government minister said lockdown rules will continue into at least next week.When the UK-wide lockdown rules were announced, prime minister Boris Johnson said they would be reviewed every three weeks.Next Monday, April , marks three weeks since the announcement.But, speaking at a press conference yesterday, the Welsh Government housing and local government minister Julie James said this was too soon to lt the lockdown and the rules would remain in force in Wales into the start of next week - and possibly further.A more formal announcement on the continuation of lockdown guidelines will be given soon."These are extraordinary times, and weve taken these measures because by working together we can slow the speed of the coronavirus," Mrs James said."We will definitely be extending the guidelines, and more formal restrictions will be announced within the next few days. title: food vouchers sent   parents vale glamorgan
story: Though schools in the Vale have been closed for normal lessons since Monday March , many continued providing free meals.But it was later discovered that only a small faction of these were being claimed.Now the parents of the  Vale pupils in receipt of free school meals have been sent vouchers, which can be used to purchase food from a local supermarket.Arrangements were put in place for Tesco and Asda vouchers to be distributed and it is hoped a similar system can be established with other food outlets, including smaller operators located in the rural Vale.Parents will receive a pound voucher every fortnight, which equates to  school meals worth pound. for each eligible child.Councillor Lis Burnett, Vale of Glamorgan Council Cabinet Member for Regeneration and Education, said: ldquoI have been immensely proud of the way council staff have responded to such dficult circumstances and there is no better example of that than within our Learning and Skills teams.ldquoIn just two days staff working there have established a completely new system for administering free school meal provision so that no child goes without.ldquoSetting up this voucher system will help ensure a great many more children get the meals they are entitled to as only a small proportion were recently being claimed from schools.ldquoThe need to develop this system so quickly inevitably means there will be some fine tuning along the way.ldquoWith that in mind, I would ask parents to let us knowthey experience any glitches in the system and thank them for their patience and title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls international cooperation tackle coronavirus new labour frontbench role
story: The MP for Cardf South and Penarth will work alongside the Shadow Foreign Secretary, Lisa Nandy, as a joint Shadow Foreign Office and International Development Minister for the African continent.He was previously appointed as Shadow Minister for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs until he resigned from the position in .During his live daily Q and A session yesterday, Mr Doughty said: "I got a call from the Sir Kier Starmer yesterday letting me know hed like me to be a Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Development."Ill be working in two dferent teams with Lisa Nandy and Preet Kaur Gill - both fantastic people and Im delighted to be working with them."And the full front bench team was announced today so it will be a delight to go back and be in a shadow ministerial role."Its something that I feel Ive got a lot to contribute on but also is going to be so crucial because were seeing the impacts that coronavirus is having in this country with a developed health system with relatively strong levels of support for people, though I appreciate at the moment its incredibly dficult for people but compared to some countries around the world who literally dont have any of the type of equipment or expertise or staffing that we do in our health service."Im really fearful of some of the impact that will have in some of the poorest countries around the world, so this is undoubtedly going to be a big issue over the next few months and Im going to be working very closely with Kiers team to make sure we get the right support from governments across the world working together because were not going to solve this crisis by putting up barriers."Sir Keir won the Labour leadership contest in the first round of voting at a ballot last week, where he competed against Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir and called his victory a ray of hope. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cafe offers delivery service help need
story: Staff at the Marie Curie Hospice in Penarth" Café offers delivery service to help those in needCharlotte Court , co-owner of Willmore#s , delivers food parcels ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtto Llandough lt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA LOCAL cafeacute has started a regular food delivery service to support frontline staff and their patients who are suffering from Covid- at Llandough Hospital.The co-owners of Willmorersquos  on Stanwell Road, Matthew Holland and Charlotte Court, have delivered over  meals to frontline facilities in Penarth since the beginning of the pandemic, including the Marie Curie Hospice on Bridgeman Road.Now the pair have plans to extend their operations.They have raised over pound for the charitable cause, which includes money collected in a fundraiser by the community support group, Helping Hands Penarth.ldquoWe closed the shop three weeks ago and used all the leftover stock to do the first delivery to the hospital, explained Matthew.ldquoWersquove all got to be doing something and we felt like we had to utilize the shop and give something back to the guys that are putting their lives at risk.ldquoPenarth is a really small town and yoursquove just got to try and support each other as much as possible.ldquoI think yoursquove got to step up and do as much as you can,you can. Wersquove got the capacity to do it.Matthew went on to describe the atmosphere at Llandough Hospital.ldquoWersquore both in Penarth and wersquove lived here all our lives. Its important to us that we support it as much as possible.ldquoIts uplting being able to do that. It was so emotional being able to see the nurses on the Covid ward.ldquoFor me and Charlotte it was very humbling because those guys are putting their lives at risk and theyrsquore asking for stuff for patients, not for themselves.ldquoWe were quite tearful because we didnrsquot want to leave them there ndash but theyrsquore doing it day in-day out without batting an eyelid. Amazing people.Alongside their charitable work, Matthew and Charlotte have adapted to the challenging economic climate by introducing a delivery service for their customers.The pair have been working without the support of their staff who they had to furlough after the government closed all non-essential shops.ldquoWersquove started doing take-out because we canrsquot afford to do nothing for three months. Wersquoll lose the shop, said Matthew.ldquoWersquoll continue to do these drop offs for the hospital as long as people fund it, and wersquoll continue to do our take-out service.ldquoBecause for shops and restaurants I think its going to be long term.ldquoWe might be in this for six months before we can open to the public.ldquoAs long as we get the support and people keep shopping locally, then yes we can get through it.ldquoRunning a business is a constant challenge and you donrsquot ever stop having to adapt. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: view westminster stephen doughty mp
story: Irsquove also recorded online conversations with council leaders and police, and these are available to view on my page at any time. With lockdown and social distancing, itrsquos crucial that we keep residents informed, and modern technology allows us to do that.One of those conversations was with Cllr Lis Burnett, Deputy Leader of the Vale Council. I raised some of the most common questions that Irsquom receiving from constituents, to find out how the authority is supporting residents, including:School provision: The Vale is using a hub system, with  schools providing services am-to-pm, seven days a week, for children of key workers and vulnerable children. Vouchers for free school meals are being issued to all who qualy every two weeks.Older shielding residents: For those without support from family and friends, the council has set up a Crisis Support Team to help with access to shopping, medication, and urgent temporary assistance. See the lsquoProtecting Vulnerable Peoplersquo section of the dedicated coronavirus page on the website www.valeofglamorgan.gov.ukBusinesses: There is a regularly-updated Business section on the councilrsquos coronavirus page, which should be the first point of call for all local businesses looking for assistance. Over pound million has already been distributed, and yoursquore encouraged to apply for support as soon as possible.Council staff: Staff are helping however they can some from non-essential services are doing waste collections, others are providing care. Itrsquos making a huge dference, and a recruitment drive for temporary care staff has also been a success.Volunteering: Local people are stepping up, and the Vale is supporting them via its Vale Heroes page on the website.Council tax bills: If you are worried about paying your council tax, get in touch with the department. They will look at every case inidually.Finally, in other news, Irsquom delighted to be taking on the role of joint Shadow Foreign and Commonwealth Office and International Development Minister covering Africa, in the new Shadow frontbench team announced by UK Labour Leader Keir Starmer. title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: charity sends letters offering support vulnerable residents
story: Dinas Powys Voluntary Concern is working in partnership with Dinas Powys Medical Centre to send a letter from the charity to around  residents in the Dinas Powys and District who have been identied as having underlying health problems.They have been advised to stay at home for a duration of  weeks during which time they should shield themselves from physical contact with others.The letter gives information about the help and support that DPVC can offer and how to contact the DPVC Coordinators, Wendy and Judith for assistance with shopping, collecting and delivering prescriptions and telephone calls at regular intervals to ensure that they are safe andany help is needed.Cllr John Fanshaw said the charity was very busy throughout the community.He said: ldquoWe are still keen to offer further assistance. title: starbucks reopen around  uk sites thursday
story: The global coffee chain said it will open around % of its UK stores in the first phase of its reopening plans, which are predominantly focused on Drive Thru stores.It said it will also reopen a ldquohandful of takeaway-only stores as it continues with preparations to allow all of its UK stores to be reopened.Starbucks closed all of its UK sites in March after the Government-mandated lockdown was introduced.The company said it has been ldquolearning, testing and refining our operational standards every day behind closed doors. vw,vw,px, px"Starbucks said it has been testing its operations behind closed doors It said the reopening plan ndash which will start with stores broadly spread across the UK ndash will focus on ensuring the health and wellbeing of its employees and customers.The reopening comes after fast food retailers, such as Burger King and KFC, have reopened Drive Thru sites.Meanwhile, some cafe chain rivals such as Pret a Manger have reopened UK sites for takeaway customers.Starbucks has already reopened some of its sites in other regions, including the US and China.It said it has ldquotaken learnings from changes to its operations in China ndash where % of sites are now open ndash and the US in consideration of its UK sites.New safety measures at UK sites will include regular hand-washing for at least  seconds, two metre social distancing, screens at payment areas and the use of contactless payment only.The reopening menu will include Starbucksrsquo core range of drinks and a limited food range, it said.Employees have been paid during the closure title: exmoor zoo celebrates birth four capybaras
story: The babies, dubbed ldquominibara by staff, are currently about the size of a guinea pig but will grow quickly.Adult capybaras reach the size of sheep, measuring  inches high and ft long, and weighing about kg.Their Latin name Hydrochoerus hydrocaheris means water hog, with their native habitat the swamps and rivers of the Amazon and south America. vw,vw,px, px"Four baby capybaras were born at Exmoor Zoo A spokesman for Exmoor Zoo said: ldquoThe wet winters here on Exmoor and fresh Atlantic rain dropped onto the moorland is perfect for these animals as it springs out from the ground creating mud wallows and bubbling brooks.ldquoNot so keen on the harsh sun though, as they have skin which needs to protection from the sun with good mud layers.ldquoWe consider with a little shelter from the worst of the winter elements and direct sun they would adapt well here.The zoo is currently closed due to lockdown restrictions.It has been running a fundraising campaign, which can be found at https:www.gofundme f save-our-zoo..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Exmoor Zoo celebrates birth of four capybaras article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: public use common sense meeting outdoors   raab
story: Boris Johnson unveiled a ldquoconditional plan on Sunday evening for easing restrictions in England, saying people could take unlimited exercise outdoors, travel to other places by car and should start going back to workthey cannot work from home.Primary schools could begin to reopen on June  starting with reception and years  and , he said, while parts of the hospitality sector such as pavement cafes and cafes in parks could open in July.But Scotland and Wales have rejected Number rsquos new ldquostay alert slogan, while unions and the Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer criticised the plan for creating confusion.On Monday, Mr Raab appeared to add to the uncertainty by saying people should only go to work from Wednesday. He also said it was fine to meet two people from another household as long as the households kept two metres apart.Government officials said on Sunday evening people should go back to work from Monday. They also said the new rules meant you could meet only one other person from another household outdoors.Speaking to the BBC on Monday, Mr Raab said people could now, for example, meet dferent family members separately on the same day while maintaining social distancing.He said: ldquoIf yoursquore out in the park and yoursquore two metres apart, wersquore saying now,use some common sense and you socially distance, you can meet up with other people.Askedsomeone could meet their mother in the morning and their father in the afternoon, he said: ldquoOutside in the outdoors, staying two metres apart, yes.When asked latersomeone could meet up with both their parents in a park, Mr Raab said: ldquoWell, you couldtherersquos two metres apart. vw,vw,px, px"However, Mr Raab said people should not play group sports such as football with other households.ldquoTwo people from the same home could go and play tennis, because thatrsquos something where they could stay two metres apart from everyone , he said.ldquoWhat you couldnrsquot then do, and this is why we say yoursquove got to stay alert, you couldnrsquot then go into the clubhouse and mill around where you will be within two metres of other people.ldquoSo, football would be one of those where I think would be very dficult to stay two metres apartyoursquore playing, you know, -a-side or even five-a-side. vw,vw,px, px"Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab Mr Raab also said people could drive as far as they wanted tothere was an outdoor area they wished to visit.He said: ldquoYou can drive as far as you want to drive to go and walk in a park or a particular area that yoursquore fond of as long as you maintain the social distancing.ldquoBut obviously,yoursquore going from one part of the UK to another, soyoursquore going from England to Wales or from Scotland to Wales and dferent rules are in place because the devolved administrations take a dferent approach, you need to be very mindful of the regulations that theyrsquove got in place.Mr Raab also urged people to go back to work from Wednesdaythey cannot work from home.ldquoIf you can work from home, you should continue to do so, but there are nine sectors of the economy like manufacturing and construction, where people canrsquot do their job from home, he said.ldquoSo wersquore saying to them they should now from Wednesday, go back to work.The PM didnrsquot say workplace changes applied from Wednesday. He said ldquoAnd the first step is a change of emphasis that we hope that people will act on this week. Wednesday was only mentioned in relation to other changes. Words matter. Clarity is essential. This is shambolic.mdash Ed MilibandMay , Shadow business secretary Ed Miliband immediately criticised the messaging, tweeting:ldquoThe PM didnrsquot say workplace changes applied from Wednesday.ldquoHe said lsquoAnd the first step is a change of emphasis that we hope that people will act on this week.rsquoldquoWednesday was only mentioned in relation to other changes. Words matter.ldquoClarity is essential. This is shambolic.On the issue of schools, Mr Raab said schools would be given ldquoclear guidance about social distancing and hygiene, adding there was a ldquomuch lower risk for young children getting this virus.But Patrick Roach, general secretary of teaching union NASUWT, said the profession has ldquovery serious concerns about children ing to school on June , adding no clear plan had been put in place.The Prime Minister is due to face MPs on Monday afternoon and will publish a -page document setting out further details of his ldquoroad map.If we all #StayAlert and follow the rules, we can control the virus by keeping the rate of infectionand the number of new cases down.Stay Alert ####Control The Virus ###Save Lives #
